eWgBU7uf7y6y0KUU9WGISxfIGwhu.title: Sandboxing Untrusted Code in Node.js
eWgBU7uf7y6y0KUU9WGISxfIGwhu.name: Joe Rozner
eWgBU7uf7y6y0KUU9WGISxfIGwhu.description: Running untrusted code is always a difficult problem to deal with. This talk will explore some of the potential problems with result from doing this including: resource starvation, data security, remote code execution, and unintended network access. It will then explore some of the design decisions of Node.JS and show how these can be used to help control provide methods to sandbox code to prevent these types of attacks, ending with an explanation of some of the limitations of this technique and possible other solutions.

HUpRCF9Fqnd8QGrnzFz2IAEA5YWo.title: meteor.js
HUpRCF9Fqnd8QGrnzFz2IAEA5YWo.name: Philippe Lewicki
HUpRCF9Fqnd8QGrnzFz2IAEA5YWo.description: Meteor is a pure javascript open source platform based on node.js, mongodb, mustache style template with optional  packages like backbone, underscore, bootstrap, coffee script, less, stylus, d3, query... I will present the key concept like live page update, synchronization, hot code push then demo some application and explain how some of the key concept are implemented.

enTvT7XHdWOZAQROtaBSBNY1Zjqm.title: Top 10 Secret Weapons For Front-End Development
enTvT7XHdWOZAQROtaBSBNY1Zjqm.name: Geoffrey Plitt
enTvT7XHdWOZAQROtaBSBNY1Zjqm.description: Geoffrey Plitt, active standup comedian, former Google engineer, and CTO of comedy discovery engine Laffster.com discusses tips, tricks, and pitfalls his teams have learned while using technologies such as KnockoutJS, HeadJS, CoffeeScript, Slim, SASS, Middleman, various jQuery plugins, and Amazon Web Services. Plus he's funny

LtwrzUfPd2rL4FSl3LoWgcEpjuPD.title: Wheatley
LtwrzUfPd2rL4FSl3LoWgcEpjuPD.name: Giles Bowkett
LtwrzUfPd2rL4FSl3LoWgcEpjuPD.description: Wheatley was designed to refactor JavaScript semi-automatically. The project's unfinished, because writing code which will refactor your JavaScript for you automatically is just insanely overambitious, but the few refactorings it can do are very cool. Wheatley can also recognize identical code and nearly-identical code. Legacy code is annoying. Imagine how cool it would be if robots would fix your legacy code for you!

hDYFYfQuQQStDu4EQBQv6IZnay3u.title: Sentiment Analysis in a Post Grammatical World
hDYFYfQuQQStDu4EQBQv6IZnay3u.name: Danny Tran, Disney
hDYFYfQuQQStDu4EQBQv6IZnay3u.description: How do we determine the sentiment of text in a world where syntax and grammer are thrown out of the window? Utilizing Node and Natural, a NLP (Natural Language Processing) toolkit, we'll go through a few techniques ranging from manual polarity determination to machine learning classification, all the while highlighting the challenges of analyzing text in a "post-grammatical" world.

Csv5V6VvcbUSktd4dzqYo4hCX9UU.title: Jukebox.js - Experiment with Modern Web Technology
Csv5V6VvcbUSktd4dzqYo4hCX9UU.name: Jeff Pelton
Csv5V6VvcbUSktd4dzqYo4hCX9UU.description: Today in the browser you can decode audio, parse metadata and album art, using Audio API & File API's, preview files on your computer using FileReader and upload them using XHR2 with HTML progress bars for the best user experience, build visualizations using a drawing library like D3.js and more. Jukebox.js is an open source experiment showing what you can do with some of the latest web technologies like file access, audio playback, chat, and real time collaboration. The web app is built with tools including backbone.js, socket.io, aurora.js, dancer.js, and more.  The server is built on house.js, a node.js open source platform as a service to provide RESTful interfaces to authentication, file systems, data and media. We'll take a quick look at the broad strategy for modern web app development, then we'll dive into as many of these great HTML features and open source javascript libraries as we can!

rfBoAuuoIriJ49oxXt2KMCzB4N1w.title: Sophisticated Views: How Ember's View Layer Handles the Complex Problems
rfBoAuuoIriJ49oxXt2KMCzB4N1w.name: Peter Wagenet
rfBoAuuoIriJ49oxXt2KMCzB4N1w.description: Simplicity is good, but what happens when your problems aren't simple? In this talk, I'll discuss some of the complexities of handling events and DOM rendering that are overlooked in many Javascript frameworks. We'll then see how Ember provides sophisticated solutions to these issues so that you don't have to.

JrjfxA2B8HOTPUDocLgz4ky6Tf9v.title: JS To Rule Them All
JrjfxA2B8HOTPUDocLgz4ky6Tf9v.name: Michael Anthony
JrjfxA2B8HOTPUDocLgz4ky6Tf9v.description: One of the more cringe-inducing terms for any JS developer is "web page". We've now reached the point where any meaningful experience needs to be an application. It also needs to be thoughtfully crafted to work on phones and tablets all the while having the level of animation and polish users have come to expect from the technology they use regardless of platform. Static pages with responsive layouts aren't going to cut it in this new universe, so we'll look at using only JavaScript to structure applications, create and style markup, and also be platform aware in order to present users with an interactive experience suited for each device. This talk will be a general theory overview accompanied by plenty of examples and very brief code demonstrations. It will cover interesting points along the way such as best practices for smooth UI and animation, content management, SEO, and even how to use these exact techniques to create native mobile applications.

sgAHgVA1fzTG09Zkml9QEMJMSZ6r.title: Backbone.js: The framework that isn't
sgAHgVA1fzTG09Zkml9QEMJMSZ6r.name: Daniel Hengeveld
sgAHgVA1fzTG09Zkml9QEMJMSZ6r.description: Backbone.js is often discussed alongside the many other popular client-side frameworks like Ember, Knockout, et cetera. This talk will discuss how Backbone.js is less like those opinionated frameworks and more like a set of glue libraries to build your own framework, and will also cover some useful patterns you can use in your own Backbone application.

p2jvff2Wus8kV9mFIfKuVCPmDl42.title: Going Native: Practical scripting with the JavaScript Image Object
p2jvff2Wus8kV9mFIfKuVCPmDl42.name: Aaron Martin
p2jvff2Wus8kV9mFIfKuVCPmDl42.description: JQuery, Dojo, Mootools, Ext, Prototype, Script.aculo.us, Backbone, Modernizer….[sigh]…it’s hard to keep up. Remember when there was just something called JavaScript? I do. Don’t get me wrong I love all the aforementioned libraries like a father loves his children, but when it is time to get practical and create performance solutions those babies got to go. I’m going to introduce you to an old friend of mine, the JavaScript native image object. This ol’boy is perhaps one of the most powerful objects in JavaScript and he’s uber simple to get to know. I’m going to show you some of his tricks and try to convince you that he belongs in your JavaScript solutions tool belt!

X4GVXKrwwYHipiIBzDZZImpaaq8w.title: AngularJS
X4GVXKrwwYHipiIBzDZZImpaaq8w.name: Igor Minar
X4GVXKrwwYHipiIBzDZZImpaaq8w.description: What if you could write modern web apps with dramatically fewer lines of code and improve its readability and expressiveness at the same time? No, there’s no new language to learn. Just familiar old HTML and JavaScript. As a matter of fact, there’s some stuff for you to un-learn. AngularJS is a client-side JavaScript web development framework where we believe we’ve done something special. We’ve approached the problem let’s say differently from the way any other JavaScript tool has before. Instead of asking what kind of functions we could provide to make writing apps smoother, we asked "what if the browser worked differently in a way that eliminates code and gives structure to apps?" This talk will take the audience on a tour of what the web platform of the future will look like and how the AngularJS framework can provide many of the powerful capabilities to existing browsers and bridge the path to web components, model driven views and other platform features that are currently being spec-ed.

ZnYSsnTK9qeGlrtrSZdEdF1qf8Wk.title: Design to Deploy - Mobile Development with Titanium
ZnYSsnTK9qeGlrtrSZdEdF1qf8Wk.name: Christian Sullivan
ZnYSsnTK9qeGlrtrSZdEdF1qf8Wk.description: This talk is about the entire process of creating a mobile application with Titanium. From the early design stage all the way through to the testing and deployment of the app and how to overcome some of the caveats that come with using Titanium.

APUQvHXOTpcF5FgIX9fLe6dvS1xr.title: Realtime Visualizations w/ D3 and Backbone
APUQvHXOTpcF5FgIX9fLe6dvS1xr.name: Andrew Cholakian
APUQvHXOTpcF5FgIX9fLe6dvS1xr.description: D3 is perhaps the most powerful tool available for displaying realtime data on the web. By defining its own level of abstraction, being closer to the DOM than charting tools (e.g. highcharts), and being higher level than drawing primitives (e.g. Raphael), you can create amazing data driven visualizations. This talk will cover the basics of D3, and best practices for integrating D3 visualizations with Backbone.js and realtime websocket data.

0qZQthkKiGC3RB99klxZi3Q0ke8v.title: Faster JavaScript Through Category Theory
0qZQthkKiGC3RB99klxZi3Q0ke8v.name: John Bender
0qZQthkKiGC3RB99klxZi3Q0ke8v.description: Math, it's certainly not something you expect to see in a presentation about JavaScript, but even this far from its ivory towers it has an important role to play. Together we'll build two categories and see how, by satisfying the category and functor laws, we can optimize our jQuery plugins and methods. Don't worry, you don't need a background in Math just some curiosity and a desire to speed up your jQuery!

1y2ruonQfYBVY01opHlfLOVouXYD.title: J3D: Adventures with WebGL
1y2ruonQfYBVY01opHlfLOVouXYD.name: Bartek Drozdz
1y2ruonQfYBVY01opHlfLOVouXYD.description: I usually find technologies that interest me, experiment with them, publish demos I do and eventually use them in a commercial project. With WebGL it was different - my first contact with this technology was through a client project. I had to learn WebGL on the go. It took me a few months to actually start apperciating it, but once the project was over and I thought I know everything about it, I decided to write my own engine that I baptized simply J3D. After a good start, I realized I didn't know that much about WebGL after all... Since then I spent many day & nights (mostly nights) learning and creating what I believe is a good tool for other developers to start creating 3D applications in the browser. In my presentation I talk about specific challenges when working WebGL projects and how J3D addresses them. I will also take you on a short walk-through of it's features and present some demos.

eS0olFngmareDYNKcz9u47Al2CY5.title: Introducing Mojito
eS0olFngmareDYNKcz9u47Al2CY5.name: Gamaiel Zavala, Yahoo!
eS0olFngmareDYNKcz9u47Al2CY5.description: Mojito is a sweet (and minty!) MVC application framework built on YUI 3 that enables agile development of Web applications. Gamaiel Zavala will be presenting an introduction to Mojito including set up, routing, controllers, models, addons, binders, and configuration. Gamaiel has been building Media sites at Yahoo! for 6 years and is currently working on Media's migration to Mojito.

3wG0o0vWTmyfnSwt6hudRpxGoScR.title: Seeing Sound with HTML5
3wG0o0vWTmyfnSwt6hudRpxGoScR.name: David Guttman
3wG0o0vWTmyfnSwt6hudRpxGoScR.description: Embrace JavaScript-induced synesthesia. Thanks to recent advances in web audio API technology, you can now see sound---in your browser. Thus, the time for in-browser music visualization is now! It's easier than ever before with EasyEars.js and David will show you how.

LX7Z1uGvayUVF1vAomBlF88VTQYc.title: Achieving Native Mobile App Performance using JavaScript
LX7Z1uGvayUVF1vAomBlF88VTQYc.name: Michael Anthonya
LX7Z1uGvayUVF1vAomBlF88VTQYc.description: JS for mobile development and getting the best performance out of CSS3 tweens.

GqSj6CqYxHMKQVQHFD5dPxqN0SuO.title: Breaking up big node.js apps into lots of tiny services
GqSj6CqYxHMKQVQHFD5dPxqN0SuO.name: James Haliday
GqSj6CqYxHMKQVQHFD5dPxqN0SuO.description: Splitting up your architecture into tiny processes that talk to each other over the network is useful for many of the same reasons that unix utilities are useful: they can focus on doing one thing well and it's trivial to glue a bunch of tiny processes together to serve some more complicated end goal. It can be difficult to write and deploy applications this way, but I've written some libraries such as dnode, upnode, seaport, and fleet to make this much easier to manage. In this talk I'll show how you can glue tiny processes together and split bigger ones up with these tools.

aZJhkB31aHQbx7MouRB8At3BhBV0.title: An Introduction to WebGL and three.js
aZJhkB31aHQbx7MouRB8At3BhBV0.name: Travis Glines
aZJhkB31aHQbx7MouRB8At3BhBV0.description: I had recently been working a lot with WebGL and three.js and will give a simple primer on what WebGL is, using three.js and how to make something neat.

FNsdzeFn0noDvlLnezdsr5DhREa5.title: Creating Thumbnails from Movies Using JS and HTML5
FNsdzeFn0noDvlLnezdsr5DhREa5.name: James Baca

29f7LDHP3o0OwXASqYvtGeKFjXVH.title: leveldb And Node.js: Choose Your Own Adventure
29f7LDHP3o0OwXASqYvtGeKFjXVH.name: Ryan Day
29f7LDHP3o0OwXASqYvtGeKFjXVH.description: The "Nodebases" have arrived. `tables flip. chairs fall` Wait.. Rather than running for the hills with screams of "making databases can't be for me" let's gear up with some node modules and talk about how we can solve data woes. You can use the level module for great success, but you will find that Leveldb and node together have all of the primitives required to create any database. it's fast and fun. lets have an adventure!

yMWgvIm9WoPbRCbif7f1hKi4YoTd.title: Practical Philosophy: Abstracting Away your Pain with JavaScript
yMWgvIm9WoPbRCbif7f1hKi4YoTd.name: Mark Nadal
yMWgvIm9WoPbRCbif7f1hKi4YoTd.description: An exploration from the fundamentals of computer science all the way up to implementing real time apps in just 8 lines of code. For most people, the latter would reek of assumption dependent frameworks, but we'll discover how to apply some primitive philosophies to escape from that pain and keep full control instead. Yes, you can have your cake and eat it too, with elegant and maintainable code - you'll laugh, you'll cry, we'll kill Socrates, and we'll cook a Kraken. Just don't bring popcorn, or it might burst the kernel into panic.

nr0Gm3MrDA14s86XwigqPp2X0GHE.title: Full Streams Ahead
nr0Gm3MrDA14s86XwigqPp2X0GHE.name: David Guttman, js.la/SPEC.LA Organizer
nr0Gm3MrDA14s86XwigqPp2X0GHE.description: Holy crap streams are awesome. Without a doubt, they are one of the coolest things to happen to JS. Data visualization and processing will never be the same. If you've never coded with streams before, or are interested in taking your game to the next level, you don't want to miss this talk.

koM0QY5DtjdLlsI0KgY0OcWQLpCJ.title: Caffeinated Rhythms: Playing Drums With CoffeeScript
koM0QY5DtjdLlsI0KgY0OcWQLpCJ.name: Giles Bowkett
koM0QY5DtjdLlsI0KgY0OcWQLpCJ.description: If you’ve ever wanted to make music with your computer, it’s easy to do. Any developer working on OS X can write CoffeeScript code which plays drum rhythms. (Solutions exist for other platforms but won’t be within the scope of this talk.) Find out how, with a simple overview of the ubiquitous music protocol MIDI, and the node-midi library which makes it easy.

796EZGF6pHOhh3KBVoTfR9SqMNsW.title: Making a Simple Game in JavaScript Step-By-Step
796EZGF6pHOhh3KBVoTfR9SqMNsW.name: Mims H. Wright, Principal Web Developer at Huge
796EZGF6pHOhh3KBVoTfR9SqMNsW.description: All games in any language start with the same basic structure. A timer updates various elements and renders them on the screen. This talk walks through the basics of making a simple game in JavaScript. We start with a game loop and progresses adding a new feature at each step along the way. The end result has graphics, physics, sprite animation, collision detection, text and sound.

cwKSbu859stg63PevEzNgFZlnCCy.title: You Got Your Audio in my Browser: An Introduction to the Web Audio API
cwKSbu859stg63PevEzNgFZlnCCy.name: Joe Rozner
cwKSbu859stg63PevEzNgFZlnCCy.description: If you ever thought it might be a good idea to build rich audio applications in the browser and cringe at the thought of using flash to do so, you're in luck.  The Web Audio API has landed in current versions of Chrome and Firefox and is ready for hacking on.  This presentation will provide an introduction to the current draft spec showing the basics of how to use the API and show examples of what it possible by leveraging it as well as some of the additional HTML 5 APIs.

c5vPPSoWjwKU805e4zOnyrY3Sr0O.title: Discovering Music Through Geo Location
c5vPPSoWjwKU805e4zOnyrY3Sr0O.name: Chris Mendez
c5vPPSoWjwKU805e4zOnyrY3Sr0O.description: In 2012, the USC Radio online team set out to create a new type of music discovery app centered around geo location. After months of imagining, planning, developing and iterating, the team finally released Geotunes, an HTML5-based app that provides users with a new way to learn about the relationships between songs and their geographical surroundings. The presentation will take a birds-eye view of the product lifecycle and share what it took to become one of the first 100 apps on the Spotify app ecosystem.

FsdH45sKJ0zixQo26CP6TDdetUic.title: Beyond JSON: On HTML5 data-types and handling bytes in the DOM well
FsdH45sKJ0zixQo26CP6TDdetUic.name: Sam L'ecuyer
FsdH45sKJ0zixQo26CP6TDdetUic.description: In this talk, Sam L'ecuyer will discuss the issues of handling binary data in the browser via JavaScript, the new ways of dealing with files, and the history that led up to it.  His presentation will not only cover the APIs that allow more native-like applications, but also a demo of a font engine in pure javascript.

sFj5D9z08pxB5y9vUrlWGtrTo8NP.title: Behind Paper.js: On the nuts and bolts of designing and building a vector graphics library in JavaScript
sFj5D9z08pxB5y9vUrlWGtrTo8NP.name: Jürg Lehni
sFj5D9z08pxB5y9vUrlWGtrTo8NP.description: As one of the creators of Paper.js, Jürg Lehni will shed light on the history and functionality of the library. His presentation will also focus on various meta-programming tricks, such as the implementation of operator overloading in JavaScript to make vector math a first class citizen, a row of other syntactic goodies that lead to more readable code, almost automatic (de)serialization of data structures, and an internal micro framework used for simple class inheritance with support for accessors and dynamic overloading.

iqlokqouMaJjdaFao3h2bBcL1NhR.title: Behind the Weird Faces: Presets as a technique for rich procedural content creation
iqlokqouMaJjdaFao3h2bBcL1NhR.name: Matthias Dörfelt
iqlokqouMaJjdaFao3h2bBcL1NhR.description: In his presentation Matthias will talk about his art project "Weird Faces" which generates an infinite number of unique faces that look very similar to his hand drawn faces. Weird Faces has been programmed in Java Script using PaperJS. In his talk he will use the project to show off the power of using presets as a technique for rich and diverse procedural and generative content creation.

NtjRBbXVwZqj2FesIAEkywfb78Bi.title: The History of Women in Computing
NtjRBbXVwZqj2FesIAEkywfb78Bi.name: Jessica Suttles
NtjRBbXVwZqj2FesIAEkywfb78Bi.description: Computer programming was once seen as "women's work." Ada Lovelace, Grace Hopper, Adele Goldberg, and others played pivotal roles in paving the way for today's computing professions. So why then do we see so few women in our community? I'll cover the history of women in computing, possible causes of the gender imbalance, and ideas for how our community can shape a future that includes more women.

nsd9Ebi7WtYTkPZdc2bMTnOtdoA2.title: Modular Widgets with AMD
nsd9Ebi7WtYTkPZdc2bMTnOtdoA2.name: Guy Bedford
nsd9Ebi7WtYTkPZdc2bMTnOtdoA2.description: Guy is the author of RequireCSS and ZestJS, which provides a way of writing widgets as AMD modules managing the templates, CSS and dynamic scripts as a single dependency for rendering both on the client and server. He will go over some of the benefits of using AMD modules with RequireJS, including how it's not really that different from CommonJS. See how features such as plugins and dynamic loading work naturally in the browser and how these allow for the ZestJS widget approach.

ORlmkJBaeXPjD4TEieHgCFCgya1R.title: JavaScript Made Simple: JavaScript Object Orientation
ORlmkJBaeXPjD4TEieHgCFCgya1R.name: Joe Johnson
ORlmkJBaeXPjD4TEieHgCFCgya1R.description: For this month's installment of JavaScript Made Simple, we talk about the Object (JavaScript's "atom"). In Object Orientation, we'll introduce you to the basics of several forms of JavaScript Object creation as well as recognizing and implementing prototypal inheritance.

KJoQPRcUajIghVrLOjuwEYlgJAfi.title: Browserify V2 and You (nix)
KJoQPRcUajIghVrLOjuwEYlgJAfi.name: James Halliday
KJoQPRcUajIghVrLOjuwEYlgJAfi.description: Browserify lets you use node-style require() calls to load files and npm modules in the browser (it's awesome). The recent browserify v2 rewrite embraces streaming APIs, lots of tiny modules all doing exactly one thing well, and timeless unix wisdom. Now you can bundle static assets with source transforms, generate compact bundles with standalone streaming pipeline tools, trivially test your modules in node and against every browser ever and other superpowers all with a new very tiny bundle filesize overhead that supports multiple bundles. Finally the sublime wisdom of node and unix can be realized all the way up the stack in browsers too.

XNHmayWHcmMjxF5ulPxKqxDcEtXg.title: Java Script Made Simple: Hip Hop Array
XNHmayWHcmMjxF5ulPxKqxDcEtXg.name: Jonny Kang
XNHmayWHcmMjxF5ulPxKqxDcEtXg.description: Short talk on arrays in javascript. For our series, Javascript Made Simple.

jrB7BQuKA5LCFgRksGOKBi7GSDDZ.title: Node's Harder Side
jrB7BQuKA5LCFgRksGOKBi7GSDDZ.name: Eric Gradman
jrB7BQuKA5LCFgRksGOKBi7GSDDZ.description: Eric Gradman is an inventor and entertainer who makes others see technology as magic. He has a colorful history as a circus performer, professional whistler, roboticist, and inventor. In this talk, Eric will discuss the challenges and rewards of interfacing with interesting hardware using Node. If you've never wondered why you'd debounce an unreliable button using Underscore, come check this talk out

uPyiV5r3mSiGGmsQcBqgL4kAm8Wi.title: Creative JavaScript in Advertising
uPyiV5r3mSiGGmsQcBqgL4kAm8Wi.name: Michael Anthony and Andy Thelander
uPyiV5r3mSiGGmsQcBqgL4kAm8Wi.description: Michael Anthony and Andy Thelander of Active Theory will look back on their first 6 months as a digital agency and share select projects like "http://cloudsovercuba.com" and "http://www.mylifein20years.com" whilst discussing development techniques of client and server-side JavaScript.

pSWcdgYtxpftmCBigSXZgrr9Fl1V.title: JavaScript Made Simple
pSWcdgYtxpftmCBigSXZgrr9Fl1V.name: Ron Evans
pSWcdgYtxpftmCBigSXZgrr9Fl1V.description: If you have never seen Ron present before you are in for a treat. This is the first in a series of very short talks (5-7 mins) which will help introduce some of the basics of JS, as well as point out some interesting aspects that perhaps even "experts" might not know.

qoyNip4yFOo6d5tPRKX3aSj3T48k.title: Node.js & Me
qoyNip4yFOo6d5tPRKX3aSj3T48k.name: Mike Brevoort
qoyNip4yFOo6d5tPRKX3aSj3T48k.description: Mike has been leading the Node.js efforts at Pearson, a global education and publishing company. He has been responsible for advocating the needs of large organizations in the node community and has unique experience integrating a diverse tech stack into a modern one that developers want to work with. Mike will share his experiences with node.js, where it's a good fit and where it is not. He will discuss some specific examples of how he's used node and dive into some code.

kC9dpFV2uCyxbO3e6TmoNmLM90XL.title: Math Envy and CoffeeScript's Foibles
kC9dpFV2uCyxbO3e6TmoNmLM90XL.name: John Bender
kC9dpFV2uCyxbO3e6TmoNmLM90XL.description: John Bender is the co-creator of Vagrant, a jQuery Mobile contributor, and a recovering polygot. During the day he works full-time on jQuery Mobile at Adobe and otherwise spends his time hacking on open source. CoffeeScript is an extremely popular JavaScript replacement, but its flexible syntax has been the source of some confusion. This talk covers one troublesome interaction between CoffeeScript terms and how mathematics could prevent similar issues in the future. You don't need a background in math to enjoy the talk, just an interest in language design and how math can help solve tough problems.

NOkbdRVGtMzKxW9fcaor2fPXoIXd.title: Ampersand.js: The Non-Frameworky Framework
NOkbdRVGtMzKxW9fcaor2fPXoIXd.name: Luke Karrys
NOkbdRVGtMzKxW9fcaor2fPXoIXd.description: Ampersand.js is a highly modular, loosely coupled, non-frameworky framework.  Composed of tiny modules, Ampersand is able to leverage the power of npm and Browserify to build advanced applications, while maximizing simplicity in the increasingly complex world of front-end application development. Learn some conventions and how to harness the flexibility of Ampersand to solve real problems presented by today's web apps.

yZRCXO2sNX7lwn8c9Vb4t4il74Py.title: A future called Web Components
yZRCXO2sNX7lwn8c9Vb4t4il74Py.name: Zeno Rocha
yZRCXO2sNX7lwn8c9Vb4t4il74Py.description: Discover how this new concept formed by five new specifications (Templates, Decorators, Shadow DOM, Custom Elements, HTML Imports) will revolutionize the way we develop for the web.

AWXb7WE6gD4cliUKUiRERCnl0hat.title: Module of the Month: Dotenv
AWXb7WE6gD4cliUKUiRERCnl0hat.name: Scott Motte
AWXb7WE6gD4cliUKUiRERCnl0hat.description: Module of the month is a segment that highlights one of the many npm modules that make Nodejs so great. This months module is Dotenv

lLSeeylWwB1pNRyKRKq6LixKWS5h.title: Node.js in Production
lLSeeylWwB1pNRyKRKq6LixKWS5h.name: Jeff Dickey
lLSeeylWwB1pNRyKRKq6LixKWS5h.description: Running Node.js in a production settings requires you to ensure stability, performance, security and maintainability—particularly challenging while the best practices in JavaScript change rapidly. Learn the pros and cons between various tools and providers whether it is deciding on a cloud provider, build system, load balancer and more. Learn about common mistakes made when moving from a development environment to production and ways to harden your system once it comes online.

NIiz4Cq4hpumrrZlN7G7Z63lMHku.title: Test-driven Development of Web Apps in Node.js
NIiz4Cq4hpumrrZlN7G7Z63lMHku.name: Tommy Stanton
NIiz4Cq4hpumrrZlN7G7Z63lMHku.description: Node.js is a natural choice for anything HTTP, so it has quickly become popular for writing web applications. As a complement, the language offers viable means of conducting test-driven development (TDD). Some of the technologies covered in this talk will be: Express, SuperAgent, Mocha, and Chai. Tommy will explain TDD basics from a Node perspective, transitioning into real examples of clever ways to prove that a web app works as advertised. The result is a surge in programmer confidence and a foundation to ensure long-term software quality!

Pqvz1b9YWaRNYmZsCn8NtwvGdRA2.title: Module of the Month: LevelUp
Pqvz1b9YWaRNYmZsCn8NtwvGdRA2.name: Jacob Lowe
Pqvz1b9YWaRNYmZsCn8NtwvGdRA2.description: First in a series of Module of the Month presentations: LevelUp

ln8thquhOtqxkW2dqyTHfluMgMfl.title: Build Systems: The Next Generation
ln8thquhOtqxkW2dqyTHfluMgMfl.name: Contra
ln8thquhOtqxkW2dqyTHfluMgMfl.description: Build systems play a crucial role in a modern web developers life. Why do we settle for subpar processes when we can have it all? Take a journey through the build system to discuss a little philosophy, automation, streams, grunt, gulp, and everything in between.

ZqFNEjG1VVxF830erHKjNxpZupJS.title: Real World React
ZqFNEjG1VVxF830erHKjNxpZupJS.name: Aaron Murray
ZqFNEjG1VVxF830erHKjNxpZupJS.description: React.js brings significant benefits to front-end development: performant virtual DOM diff, one-way data flow and a great component system. React, however, is just the "V" in MVC, so the question of how to actually architect your application quickly arises. Explore using React to build full apps including complementary libs, tooling, pain points and more.

9xIfpt78Rpp9HJsj8HIogsJlnb8Y.title: Building Realtime Apps and Developer Communities at Firebase
9xIfpt78Rpp9HJsj8HIogsJlnb8Y.name: Sara Robinson
9xIfpt78Rpp9HJsj8HIogsJlnb8Y.description: Firebase is a realtime API that lets you store and sync data instantly. Learn how you can use Firebase to build a web or mobile app in minutes without worrying about wiring up a backend. In this session, Sara will do some live coding and deploy an app using Firebase Hosting. She'll also talk about her experience building a community of JavaScript developers at Firebase.

BE8kHdycXKGOa9UrkFrZA0pn1uKR.title: Twilio & WebRTC Turns Your Browser Into a Phone
BE8kHdycXKGOa9UrkFrZA0pn1uKR.name: Carter Rabasa
BE8kHdycXKGOa9UrkFrZA0pn1uKR.description: WebRTC is revolutionizing the way we handle voice, video and data communication by providing native peer-to-peer communication inside the browser. However unless you're familiar with terms like STUN and TURN, actually deploying an end-to-end WebRTC solution is difficult. At Twilio we use WebRTC to power Twilio Client which enables web developers to embed VOIP in their applications. In this talk I'll provide an overview of how Twilio works and do some live coding with Twilio Client and Node to turn my browser into a phone.

i9tEWrV7KbkV1Yw1AYKUmwUANdRo.title: WebTorrent: How I built a BitTorrent client in the browser
i9tEWrV7KbkV1Yw1AYKUmwUANdRo.name: Feross
i9tEWrV7KbkV1Yw1AYKUmwUANdRo.description: WebRTC changes everything! For the first time, we can do peer-to-peer, or client-to-client, communication in the browser without plugins, extensions, or a software installation. This enables an entirely new class of applications to be built for the web! This talk will look at WebTorrent, a BitTorrent client for the browser that fully-interoperates with the regular BitTorrent network. WebTorrent uses WebRTC Data Channels and special "hybrid clients" to connect to the wider BitTorrent network. By making BitTorrent easier, we're making it accessible to new swathes of users who were previously intimidated, confused, or unwilling to install a program on their computer to participate.

n6Bveqrsw8Fp8hVTJrVOWZkraaOZ.title: Native NodeJS Apps
n6Bveqrsw8Fp8hVTJrVOWZkraaOZ.name: Jacob Lowe
n6Bveqrsw8Fp8hVTJrVOWZkraaOZ.description: Native NodeJS apps are a relatively new breed of apps coming out of the NodeJS community that combine NodeJS and Webkit. Ill be going over : what are the options out there, what kind of things can these apps do compared to webapps, what are the current pro/cons of making a NodeJS native app, and more.

3h93laL8wkEkfDRAwi93OiLQLgro.title: Static Web Architecture: Not Just for Hipsters
3h93laL8wkEkfDRAwi93OiLQLgro.name: Michael Bleigh
3h93laL8wkEkfDRAwi93OiLQLgro.description: Building with a separated front and back end makes your applications more scalable, flexible, and modular. Learn the ropes of Service-Oriented Architecture, CORS, authentication, and more for static web apps.

93Ncl6Eo9cLlVqMUNeMyXnkApHui.title: The Intranet of Things with Node.js
93Ncl6Eo9cLlVqMUNeMyXnkApHui.name: Brian Johnson
93Ncl6Eo9cLlVqMUNeMyXnkApHui.description: Universal Controller is a node.js based application intended to run on a device within a local network - preferrably a dedicated server (such as a Raspberry Pi). It allows all web capable devices within that same network to issue commands to any other configured device. You may use your phone, tablet, desktop or laptop browser to interact with any controllable device - or issue simple GET commands programmatically.

KEP0oMDOkls3SEd3opVXVnVxvRtY.title: AngularJS: The Awesome Parts
KEP0oMDOkls3SEd3opVXVnVxvRtY.name: Ari Lerner
KEP0oMDOkls3SEd3opVXVnVxvRtY.description: AngularJS is the hottest framework on the web. Come and take a whirlwind tour of Angular and why it has such explosive growth. In this talk, you’ll learn why Angular and then jump right into feeling how powerful it is to build an Angular app (even if you’ve never touched it before). Ari Lerner, the author of the canonical book on Angular will walk you through it’s powerful features. You’ll start building your own Angular apps in no time.

veWwXzmF3EGXqjSIEAEkmB8AmEk6.title: Deprecating the Password
veWwXzmF3EGXqjSIEAEkmB8AmEk6.name: Scott Motte
veWwXzmF3EGXqjSIEAEkmB8AmEk6.description: Scott Motte of SendGrid talks on deprecating the password. Learn about an alternative authentication system - called handshake.js - that is passwordless and uses email only. Make users lives easier and more secure not having to remember a password. See a live demo of it in action and how easy it is to add to your next app using only JavaScript.

FOma0ef9FRPx3VKtlH4bwKt1JY58.title: Taking over the NES with JavaScript
FOma0ef9FRPx3VKtlH4bwKt1JY58.name: Michael Matuzak
FOma0ef9FRPx3VKtlH4bwKt1JY58.description: The 8-bit classic that started the home video game revolution, now hackable with JavaScript. Learn how to write text to the screen, load sprites and more.

Lsrz4uRdx3N7vdn5qTtRupFXGSlD.title: WebGL, What The Hell
Lsrz4uRdx3N7vdn5qTtRupFXGSlD.name: Giles Bowkett
Lsrz4uRdx3N7vdn5qTtRupFXGSlD.description: WebGL stands for Web Graphics Library. A name so dull and generic may surprise you if you're used to hipster naming conventions, and could cover everything from generating GIFs (hard G for life) to the prepackaged icons you can find in Twitter Bootstrap. But immense power lurks behind this bland name. WebGL lets you put GPU graphics in a <canvas> element, and it powers terrific games, infographics, and demoscene-style visuals. Giles Bowkett will blunder through this library, attempting to make it do things, and tell you all about it.

mOFQLV0GECQlwoTTIJLhSkvtJlay.title: Node.JS and Docker with a side of Continuous Deployment
mOFQLV0GECQlwoTTIJLhSkvtJlay.name: Niall O'Higgins
mOFQLV0GECQlwoTTIJLhSkvtJlay.description: Docker is an incredible new tool to manage the deployment and lifecycle of Node.JS network services. This talk will cover using them together for much Continuous Deployment win

jFJ0WzFVS88qLqrL40nVZEcuPXdE.title: Hanging up on Callbacks: Generators in ES6
jFJ0WzFVS88qLqrL40nVZEcuPXdE.name: Erin Swenson-Healey
jFJ0WzFVS88qLqrL40nVZEcuPXdE.description: While the JavaScript event loop and asynchronous callbacks provide a powerful, easy-to-understand concurrency model - writing applications in continuation-passing style introduces problems of legibility, exception management, and composability. With the introduction of generators in the ECMAScript 6 Draft Specification, programmers can continue to leverage the power of the single-threaded event loop while writing expressive, simple code in a direct, top-down style.

p5bnOWtktDdtTFy2MdW7B3cMdONl.title: Coordinated Concurrency: Reactive (Observables) vs. CSP
p5bnOWtktDdtTFy2MdW7B3cMdONl.name: Kyle Simpson
p5bnOWtktDdtTFy2MdW7B3cMdONl.description: A lot of hype is building recently around reactive programming (aka observables), which models interactions as the composition and consumption of streams of events (data flowing through steps). But is that exclusively the right path for truly next-gen async programming?

FcMsLOyiZ1x2BZxMAQY6uSQs6Hgc.title: Mapping LA: Building Immersive Apps with Geodata
FcMsLOyiZ1x2BZxMAQY6uSQs6Hgc.name: Sam L'Ecuyer
FcMsLOyiZ1x2BZxMAQY6uSQs6Hgc.description: There's an astonishing amount of geographic data out there. And there are a ton of ways to process it. Still, most people can only name one or two mapping products to use in webapps. Sam will talk about what this data is, where to find it, how to make it look great, and how to make it meaningful.

Xxp2PnTX0kpmAwb9n9e4DPzzvocj.title: Generative art and music
Xxp2PnTX0kpmAwb9n9e4DPzzvocj.name: Patrick Gunderson
Xxp2PnTX0kpmAwb9n9e4DPzzvocj.description: There are some things that people do much better than computers. People emote and intuit ideas seemingly out of nowhere while computers must have a defined procedure to follow in whatever they do. In this talk, Patrick will discuss how he's used sine waves to and parametric design to give computers an unsteady hand and the ability to compose music on-the-fly.

VmHYUPbONE2cDQEh0bheRg8uJmcj.title: We Don't Need No Stinking Browser - How to Build a CLI Based SaaS
VmHYUPbONE2cDQEh0bheRg8uJmcj.name: Brock Whitten
VmHYUPbONE2cDQEh0bheRg8uJmcj.description: Browsers are so 2015. The SaaS of tomorrow is fast, powerful, and most importantly, composable. We'll look behind the scenes to see how Surge, the zero-bullshit web publishing CDN is built.

92zlwoGeq3WOZGNhC97IAH2R8AfF.title: Native Mobile Apps in Javascript - Just Add Cordova! (and a Pinch of Command-Line)
92zlwoGeq3WOZGNhC97IAH2R8AfF.name: Wren Reynolds
92zlwoGeq3WOZGNhC97IAH2R8AfF.description: Apache Cordova, the free open-source engine behind PhoneGap, builds native apps from Javascript and opens up device features with a handy API. Taking the absolute essentials from a 3-hour "Intro to Cordova" workshop, this talk makes cooking native apps less like prepping a 5-course dinner with Gordon Ramsay screaming in your face, and more like making mom's spaghetti.

igoy8dwpSZjGGbtQguP4h1On9wbU.title: Carefully Composing Logic: Functional JavaScript
igoy8dwpSZjGGbtQguP4h1On9wbU.name: Brad Urani
igoy8dwpSZjGGbtQguP4h1On9wbU.description: Functional programming is the rage, but you don't need to learn a functional language to get started doing it. In fact, JavaScript has had almost everything you need to program in a purely functional style from the beginning. In this talk, we'll explore the basics of functional programming - higher-order functions, lazy evaluation and immutable persistent data structures. We'll see how a functional style helps you compose logic in a way that's clean, testable and free of certain classes of bugs. Then we'll tie it together into a purely functional style by demonstrating a clever algorithmic game solver.

kuLrFpeb9BDidUL1ba9f6pS39vSK.title: My phone runs on JavaScript ;)
kuLrFpeb9BDidUL1ba9f6pS39vSK.name: Reza Akhavan
kuLrFpeb9BDidUL1ba9f6pS39vSK.description:
Have you seen FirefoxOS lately? This talk is going to re-introduce you to why it's not only cool to have an operating system built with Web technologies, but why it's necessary.

FirefoxOS is designed to provide a complete, community-based alternative for mobile devices, using open standards such as HTML5, JavaScript and open web APIs that allow us to communicate directly with device hardware.

7vdsP5gUYrhmkI9FAC7gpTi6Fwqz.title: Don't Over React, ES.Next Component Guide
7vdsP5gUYrhmkI9FAC7gpTi6Fwqz.name: Robbie dela Victoria
7vdsP5gUYrhmkI9FAC7gpTi6Fwqz.description: Get up and running with React and ES6 aka ES2015. Common design patterns, Common pitfalls, and more.

dK1we7XhzpiyD6kugckNI2RpNKZ7.title: Module of the Month: PostCSS
dK1we7XhzpiyD6kugckNI2RpNKZ7.name: Nate Lubeck
dK1we7XhzpiyD6kugckNI2RpNKZ7.description: Module of the month is a segment that highlights one of the many npm modules that make Node.js so great. This month's module is PostCSS

pAfR4vxNKBPdLO8dm5MTpPrmj7er.title: Successfully Hacking in Your Spare Time
pAfR4vxNKBPdLO8dm5MTpPrmj7er.name: Bryan Hughes
pAfR4vxNKBPdLO8dm5MTpPrmj7er.description: Hacking in your spare time is a lot of fun, but how do you actually finish that project you've been dreaming about? This talk will discuss these constraints and requirements, and how a little creativity goes a long way. Key to this is dreaming big while being realistic, and just getting something out there is important. I will also discuss the role of open source in personal projects, from leveraging existing work to how you actually open source a project properly.

YULFzgmIEJyauYOoY4chl9gJRaTm.title: Scalable and Maintainable React
YULFzgmIEJyauYOoY4chl9gJRaTm.name: Lawrence Lau
YULFzgmIEJyauYOoY4chl9gJRaTm.description: React is created for building large web applications with data that changes in response to actions over time. This is exactly what many of our user-facing products are doing. Yet like many other application frameworks, scalability and maintainability are not inherent, because you are still free to organize your application as long as you follow the unidirectional flow. This talk will share lessons learned from my React application development with code samples at different stages of the unidirectional flow with the goal to truly take advantage of React to build a scalable and maintainable application.

ro3pdLFrTwbN3siovbswXsb5cMP4.title: Data Painting: A graphical programming environment for making art with GPIO on the Intel Galileo
ro3pdLFrTwbN3siovbswXsb5cMP4.name: Eric Gradman
ro3pdLFrTwbN3siovbswXsb5cMP4.description: The Intel Galileo is a pretty powerful little board. It comes pre-installed with node.js, and you can use it to interface with electronic components. In collaboration with Intel, we developed a kit to acquaint kids with functional programming concepts and basic electronics through artistic expression. The interface is a simple webpage served by the Galileo. Using a Google Blockly graphical interface, kids connect nodes representing graphical elements to nodes representing switches and sliders connected to the Galileo. And just like that… art.

NOccTciJUf31ymIydDlaOyJ6P9Hn.title: Building Intelligent Devices for the Internet of Things: Lessons Learned from the Chain Check Project
NOccTciJUf31ymIydDlaOyJ6P9Hn.name: Bill Pierce
NOccTciJUf31ymIydDlaOyJ6P9Hn.description: In 2014, Intel launched the Edison, a tiny single board computer targeting the Internet of Things (IoT) and wearables markets. The Edison supports a full-featured Linux distro, providing a natural platform for rapid prototyping of IoT projects including Node.js and wifi connectivity out of the box. In this talk, I’ll present our experience using the Edison on the Chain Check project, applying machine learning and digital signal processing techniques to predictive maintenance for bicycles.

i2fD9rNgRVTgCD5rUS0EB1fgqHIO.title: Module of the Month: Babel
i2fD9rNgRVTgCD5rUS0EB1fgqHIO.name: Jacob Lowe
i2fD9rNgRVTgCD5rUS0EB1fgqHIO.description: Module of the month is a segment that highlights one of the many npm modules that make Node.js so great. This month's module is babel

TZN6Vp3k7K1jgothmbZe3i2UMT8G.title: Decentralized Databases, and the End of the Web Host
TZN6Vp3k7K1jgothmbZe3i2UMT8G.name: Paul Frazee
TZN6Vp3k7K1jgothmbZe3i2UMT8G.description: How do we synchronize user devices without using servers or central coordination? Join us for a discussion of content-addressing, secure data structures, the web of trust, and apps-development in a post-host Web.

mDIOowSRcT036JPK4Hv02XI2BDre.title: npm-Registry@2.0
mDIOowSRcT036JPK4Hv02XI2BDre.name: Ben Coe
mDIOowSRcT036JPK4Hv02XI2BDre.description: npm has been in the process of rewriting their backend infrastructure. Ben, lead developer of the registry, will be talking to you about the motivations for the rewrite, and the approach that has been taken.

RE2KftxluVTWo9CFoLdt3PhzCbUN.title: Module of the Month: keystone
RE2KftxluVTWo9CFoLdt3PhzCbUN.name: Hung Q Tran
RE2KftxluVTWo9CFoLdt3PhzCbUN.description: Module of the month is a segment that highlights one of the many npm modules that make Node.js so great. This month's module is keystone

ddlheXENUOffa7mNK70jIk8VOIzJ.title: How launching Icecomm on HN created the most curious chat roulette ever (and how you can too)
ddlheXENUOffa7mNK70jIk8VOIzJ.name: Will Sentance/Tony Rizko
ddlheXENUOffa7mNK70jIk8VOIzJ.description: Icecomm lets you take full advantage of WebRTC in under 10 lines of frontend javascript. Learn how to use Icecomm to build a multiway video chat app in minutes without worrying about backend code. To get us started I'll explain some Icecomm basics, we'll live code the video chat app together and we'll even give you a sneak peak of a brand new Icecomm SDK that lets you add video and audio chat right inside emails

nPQOuJDktrOljFdJRKzz34beYAB1.title: UX for Developers
nPQOuJDktrOljFdJRKzz34beYAB1.name: Calley Nye
nPQOuJDktrOljFdJRKzz34beYAB1.description: What good is it to make an app if no one will use it? This talk will aim to demystify the broad discipline of user experience, and introduce some core concepts and methods. These concepts will help you develop a useable application, acquire users and keep them coming back for more.

Q76ZZpPBcsTeUgBL64zS4NDERmTQ.title: Module of the Month: ReactPivot
Q76ZZpPBcsTeUgBL64zS4NDERmTQ.name: David Guttman
Q76ZZpPBcsTeUgBL64zS4NDERmTQ.description: Module of the month is a segment that highlights one of the many npm modules that make Node.js so great. This month's module is ReactPivot

9pOBAPakIEIlVKAhqrV0w8r9yZmF.title: PhantomJS Under the Hood.
9pOBAPakIEIlVKAhqrV0w8r9yZmF.name: Buddy Sandidge
9pOBAPakIEIlVKAhqrV0w8r9yZmF.description: This talk goes into lessons learned from writing a sizeable PhantomJS application. We'll examine the architecture of the PhantomJS application itself and what the implications are for developers. We'll also look at best practices for using 3rd party libraries and running unit tests.

7iT67OY7UaCDVoFZqxiWrYnOEvVh.title: Monitoring Applications with StatsD
7iT67OY7UaCDVoFZqxiWrYnOEvVh.name: Advait Shinde
7iT67OY7UaCDVoFZqxiWrYnOEvVh.description: StatsD is a generic, lightweight, flexible protocol/daemon that allows you to keep track of application-specific time series metrics. It's a dead-simple approach that enables developers to instrument their applications with granular monitoring before even deploying to production.

iS3u6MpgLupq16Ef7Vgc1E6DmYPz.title: Module of the Month: Request
iS3u6MpgLupq16Ef7Vgc1E6DmYPz.name: Greg Cardoni
iS3u6MpgLupq16Ef7Vgc1E6DmYPz.description: Module of the month is a segment that highlights one of the many npm modules that make Nodejs so great. This months module is Request

WfWkKa2UVScR27oQu4A0ESnOkTiS.title: Lovefield: a powerful Javascript SQL-like database query engine for the web.
WfWkKa2UVScR27oQu4A0ESnOkTiS.name: Demetrios Papadopoulos
WfWkKa2UVScR27oQu4A0ESnOkTiS.description: Lovefield is providing a feature rich, cross-browser database query engine built using IndexedDB as a backend. It provides an intuitive SQL-like declarative syntax and it is closing a gap in the web development ecosystem that was created by the deprecation of WebSQL back in 2010.

P1MhTT2nSGcMi89hGJXHITYUfbI0.title: How to effortlessly integrate Three.js into your projects
P1MhTT2nSGcMi89hGJXHITYUfbI0.name: Jason Farrell
P1MhTT2nSGcMi89hGJXHITYUfbI0.description: This talk will focus on how to add 3D animation to real-world projects. It'll cover the basics of how to get started with Three.js, and how to build animated interactions that can be used in seemingly normal web apps.

sHTO3AIVEalbQZ1VEEjsjFcYbqpt.title: Module of the Month: Sinon
sHTO3AIVEalbQZ1VEEjsjFcYbqpt.name: Helior Colorado
sHTO3AIVEalbQZ1VEEjsjFcYbqpt.description: Module of the month is a segment that highlights one of the many npm modules that make Node.js so great. This months module is Sinon

tANrp1MKCeIuFB93nWzTtkeDXId6.title: Common Operations Challenges with Node.js and How to Solve Them
tANrp1MKCeIuFB93nWzTtkeDXId6.name: Chris Lea

sFsqJz2XPr7VFtM7TZusFDCanHKQ.title: JS to Slick Native Mobile Apps: A Future-Featured Framework
sFsqJz2XPr7VFtM7TZusFDCanHKQ.name: Wren Reynolds

ATxpNCmIm9Ul3FnqyWbdCT8CI0ra.title: Why d3 will be the standard for web visualization
ATxpNCmIm9Ul3FnqyWbdCT8CI0ra.name: Aman Tsegai

DcOeFeGz8wCHLCxOgK6OX29rxHLM.title: 10 Secrets to Writing Perfect Code — You Won’t Believe #4!
DcOeFeGz8wCHLCxOgK6OX29rxHLM.name: Ray Muneton

SPbH14ucPRMgU0WFf8fD3tIzLnCK.title: Javascript Testing - Unit tests, TDD, BDD, IDK.
SPbH14ucPRMgU0WFf8fD3tIzLnCK.name: Sara Raasch

OMS39pYbWgxk6gMk6GnvbY6hSDoa.title: Using Babel in a Modern Working Environment
OMS39pYbWgxk6gMk6GnvbY6hSDoa.name: Kurtis Rainbolt-Greene

Y230cUdh38cCfvLLlXwHwujQqFvi.title: Constructing DSLs to Automate Automation
Y230cUdh38cCfvLLlXwHwujQqFvi.name: Prakash Venkatraman
Y230cUdh38cCfvLLlXwHwujQqFvi.description: There are plenty of tools out there that make developers' jobs easy. But not all go far enough. Sometimes to automate the things that matter you need instructions specific enough to cover your project but abstract enough to be reusable. I developed a domain specific language for deploying web apps. The moral of the story is: don't just use languages.  Make them.

r5E3KNQsqCSGUQFOz4wdJRIaS6pv.title: Code without Keywords
r5E3KNQsqCSGUQFOz4wdJRIaS6pv.name: Sam L'ecuyer
r5E3KNQsqCSGUQFOz4wdJRIaS6pv.description: Let's explore math without numeric literals, data without vars, and high order functions as primitives.  Basically, let's talk Church Encoding and build real programs that don't use any construct except => functions.

rqHtbLvlmcwRvx1eX0qEo9TypSP4.title: Destroyer of the Monolith APIs
rqHtbLvlmcwRvx1eX0qEo9TypSP4.name: David Slone
rqHtbLvlmcwRvx1eX0qEo9TypSP4.description: Falcor is a framework that utilizes JSON Graph a new convention for modeling graph data. JSON Graph allows delivery an entire graph object in a very simple javascript object that allows Falcor to return data from multiple microservices simultaneously. This talk will cover the basics of JSON Graph beginning with making your first client side request to understanding the data being returned from a Falcor Router and how to create routes in Falcor router that return data from multiple microservices in a single request.

71siCWdA8WdBWGMdSrXib8U10jzI.title: Secure Coding with Node.js
71siCWdA8WdBWGMdSrXib8U10jzI.name: Seth Law
71siCWdA8WdBWGMdSrXib8U10jzI.description: As we all knew it would, JavaScript has finally overtaken the server. This departure from the client to the server introduces a number of security issues and problems that the language does not handle by default. This talk will cover and demonstrate prevalent security vulnerabilities in Node.js applications. In addition, it will address existing security controls within JavaScript code through the use of an intentionally vulnerable Node.js application.

m6MfOCgOdaRsbVqmoncBv6tnc7Fn.title: The sad, strange tale of the boy with only two fingers OR an introduction to how binary is used to make websites
m6MfOCgOdaRsbVqmoncBv6tnc7Fn.name: Mims H. Wright
m6MfOCgOdaRsbVqmoncBv6tnc7Fn.description: Most people know that computers are "just a bunch of ones and zeroes," but few understand what that really means. How do ones and zeros become numbers, words, and pictures? This talk starts at the beginning, explaining binary numbers and shows how they are used to describe basic datatypes. We begin to uncover what the statement "just a bunch of ones and zeroes" really means.

wjJM3aQ1nyl2dQk0Ht3QqrHwQP6H.title: Bringing Open-Source Practices to Your Day Job
wjJM3aQ1nyl2dQk0Ht3QqrHwQP6H.name: Ben Coe
wjJM3aQ1nyl2dQk0Ht3QqrHwQP6H.description: npm has built a community that allows millions of JavaScript developers to build together on a daily basis. From this community great software development practices have emerged: unit-testing, test-coverage, modularity. In this talk Ben will discuss how, and why, you should bring these practices to work with you.

yLchrvVmHmvpE2U9F9lNcP7gPCMK.title: Crashing the Mobile Party
yLchrvVmHmvpE2U9F9lNcP7gPCMK.name: Brian Satorius
yLchrvVmHmvpE2U9F9lNcP7gPCMK.description: Native Apps vs. Hybrid vs. Mobile Web. Can a single Javascript codebase be your cross-platform strategy with today’s tools? Learn through the pitfalls and successes we’ve had at PartyOn, the social music app that uses geolocation, web sockets, and music streaming to improve parties

O8v7pQ0MCQP2QSmu6pC77MZ1Ljb5.title: Reactive Programming for Couch Potatoes
O8v7pQ0MCQP2QSmu6pC77MZ1Ljb5.name: Andrew Hao
O8v7pQ0MCQP2QSmu6pC77MZ1Ljb5.description: You've heard the hype about functional reactive programming and how it's the bee's knees. But... you can't figure out how it works, and all the math-talk and theory jargon that surround the subject are confusing to you.

EN3E6xPZ3NmvXK9Qqe4LFN2qvdbw.title: High performance apps with DoneJS
EN3E6xPZ3NmvXK9Qqe4LFN2qvdbw.name: Justin Meyer
EN3E6xPZ3NmvXK9Qqe4LFN2qvdbw.description: This sentence is wasting your time before you get to useful information. How annoying is that? Annoyed is how your users feel if they can’t see their content immediately while too much JavaScript and CSS downloads too slowly.

TcI9VHUw6m7graxYS4tVPcZOwLBy.title: Getting Started with React Native
TcI9VHUw6m7graxYS4tVPcZOwLBy.name: Scott Motte
TcI9VHUw6m7graxYS4tVPcZOwLBy.description: Module of the Month: React Native

ta8cm3iyHpGLymLLi41PaVcJq5TM.title: Rendering with React
ta8cm3iyHpGLymLLi41PaVcJq5TM.name: Michael Jackson
ta8cm3iyHpGLymLLi41PaVcJq5TM.description: The virtual DOM abstraction created by React.js has changed the way the entire industry thinks about rendering web sites. Let's talk about what makes it special, and the cool stuff we can do with it!

Kw6QFk8mqrGiFSSRQfBR87YGuQQH.title: Scalable Authentication for Microservices and Single Page Apps
Kw6QFk8mqrGiFSSRQfBR87YGuQQH.name: David Guttman
Kw6QFk8mqrGiFSSRQfBR87YGuQQH.description: Back in the dark ages of 2015, setting up authentication for microservices and SPAs was a huge PITA. Thankfully, it's now 2016 and it's dead simple. We'll go over what's needed for modern authentication and how easy it is to get it all working with Authentic.

h0jYhgzhiXyYWmMVaafMAlJAFZOX.title: Let’s talk about SRI
h0jYhgzhiXyYWmMVaafMAlJAFZOX.name: Justin Dorfman
h0jYhgzhiXyYWmMVaafMAlJAFZOX.description: Subresource Integrity (SRI) is an up and coming web security standard from the W3C. SRI enables browsers to verify that files are delivered without unexpected manipulation. This talk will go over the history and ways to generate SRI hashes so you can start protecting your end users.

rA87PHh73I7kbc7fbtC0wdVFvIUL.title: You Get What You Give
rA87PHh73I7kbc7fbtC0wdVFvIUL.name: Rouzbeh Sarrafieh
rA87PHh73I7kbc7fbtC0wdVFvIUL.description: Contributing to OSS isn’t as hard as you think it is. How I became a top 10 contributor on big open source projects like Webpack and you can too.

Ww1lPq9LxcPNCFIo9oYpI7s0X11G.title: Peer to Peer Video Streaming with WebRTC
Ww1lPq9LxcPNCFIo9oYpI7s0X11G.name: Brian Mau
Ww1lPq9LxcPNCFIo9oYpI7s0X11G.description: WebRTC is a technology that is rapidly stabilizing, and it belongs in your tool-belt. Lets demystify it by building a peer to peer video streaming app.

N8agJVvMx7GotQBcc4C4hhhZvsGM.title: Using Babel in a Futuristic Working Environment
N8agJVvMx7GotQBcc4C4hhhZvsGM.name: Kurtis Rainbolt-Greene
N8agJVvMx7GotQBcc4C4hhhZvsGM.description: Babel, how it's progressed, the future of web development, and what it solves today.

EpzVxg82yb650yBeiFz3tQNtR97g.title: Why you should (almost) always use stateful components in React
EpzVxg82yb650yBeiFz3tQNtR97g.name: Aaron Craig
EpzVxg82yb650yBeiFz3tQNtR97g.description: A talk about the tradeoffs between stateful and stateless components, and why you might be doing it wrong.

12DOzL8JkfID7FqfONlI1V7Izh93.title: The Peer-to-peer Web
12DOzL8JkfID7FqfONlI1V7Izh93.name: Paul Frazee
12DOzL8JkfID7FqfONlI1V7Izh93.description:
We love the Web because it's open, free, and highly connected. But sometimes the Web falls short: big businesses are centralizing control, data is getting tied up on servers, and users are losing their privacy.

How can we solve these problems, and decentralize the Web?

Let's take a fresh look at peer-to-peer technologies, and see just how far the Web can go with a new protocol in the browser.

EmqieQ0c0TCxDyK9DVA26ewvHLRZ.title: Preventing Accessibility Penalties at the NFL
EmqieQ0c0TCxDyK9DVA26ewvHLRZ.name: James Hush
EmqieQ0c0TCxDyK9DVA26ewvHLRZ.description: NFL.com didn't just receive a surface level makeover, a lot of time was put into accessibility. I'll speak about how we took our video player accessibility rating all the way to the endzone. In the process, I'll show how to diagnose, debug, fix, and prevent accessibility issues in modern web applications.

4yrZ2gZHS2GfF5SabCTnMmOdDbXq.title: Reshape: Transform HTML With Javascript Plugins
4yrZ2gZHS2GfF5SabCTnMmOdDbXq.name: Jeff Escalante
4yrZ2gZHS2GfF5SabCTnMmOdDbXq.description: Introduction to Reshape, a library that opens up opportunity to transform and extend html, as well as some examples of innovation in static tech using it.

IrzQTNGIlHB7ReCXNW2OyZXikjFH.title: The Rise of the Sound-Reactive, Beat-Detecting, Robotic Browser VJ
IrzQTNGIlHB7ReCXNW2OyZXikjFH.name: David Guttman

7TR4ulmD69ApAipTCj1Rqqwm3ddV.title: Web APIs you (probably) didn’t know existed
7TR4ulmD69ApAipTCj1Rqqwm3ddV.name: Zeno Rocha

QAHK8xZtlRUloZOCFapAIBdfzTVN.title: High Performance Node.js: learn how to full throttle your code
QAHK8xZtlRUloZOCFapAIBdfzTVN.name: Lauren Spiegel & Giorgio Regni

rqH1hCfbXJqqIUQpe4QZkILH1Gsz.title: Query the shit out of Facebook's Graph API
rqH1hCfbXJqqIUQpe4QZkILH1Gsz.name: Loren Stewart

TrNmn5HMBmcqk1bHEZuXw7HvvjXy.title: Building Offline First apps with Hoodie
TrNmn5HMBmcqk1bHEZuXw7HvvjXy.name: Gregor Martynus

ffISuBJONEdu8zap8pH073rb1LXf.title: bomBora -  How to hold down your Vegemite In a NonStop Sea of Waves
ffISuBJONEdu8zap8pH073rb1LXf.name: Keith Moore
ffISuBJONEdu8zap8pH073rb1LXf.description: Porting and maintaining a native V8 engine in a car that never stops.

jzB13vH67lWYBA8StpnXYh2GTk9Z.title: Evolution
jzB13vH67lWYBA8StpnXYh2GTk9Z.name: Mateusz Marpi Marcinowski
jzB13vH67lWYBA8StpnXYh2GTk9Z.description: Marpi gets deep into generative 3D creatures/worlds with webVR, webGL, shaders, mobile, socket servers, and more ⚡️. He currently works at Obscura Digital :D

tR6fQIHNZKgyXBHd4aLbXBH69YXN.title: You Might Not Need Browser Layout
tR6fQIHNZKgyXBHd4aLbXBH69YXN.name: Max Harris
tR6fQIHNZKgyXBHd4aLbXBH69YXN.description: I built a library that helps you build UIs that render to pure SVG (no HTML, no CSS). It handles layout without relying on the browser's layout engine, implements its own shape picking system, events, provides a scrollable text-wrapping component, replaces the browser's input element with a new one, supports drag-and-drop, has a built-in dynamic layout editor, and is currently a React library

dCa1wELvN7lvJkGnD2lGzBcp0Hua.title: 🎼Web Audio Visualization Applied to Speech 🗣
dCa1wELvN7lvJkGnD2lGzBcp0Hua.name: Fabien Lemaitre
dCa1wELvN7lvJkGnD2lGzBcp0Hua.description: How do you leverage web technologies for visualizing speech? We'll cover a bit of the theory behind the Web Audio apis and libraries. Then we'll look at different ways we can visualize the vocal audio data. Finally, we'll explore more advanced techniques such as real time vocal analysis.

OnzsPn1JUei0Vad7aT3P8fDzrHWK.title: How I made a table with 10 million rows
OnzsPn1JUei0Vad7aT3P8fDzrHWK.name: Tony Germaneri
OnzsPn1JUei0Vad7aT3P8fDzrHWK.description:
I had a requirement to show tens of thousands of rows of data for a client, the solution? Use immediate drawing mode canvas to create a virtual table of much data.

I'd like to talk about algorithm complexity (big O notation) issues encountered while dealing with large arrays and in general how it effects front end web performance. If there's time, we can even go over using the web component spec to create the project aka the new hotness.

7qAJu2nRIRGiG6RGpwDwVRCU33qB.title: Building Beautiful Websites with Gatsby
7qAJu2nRIRGiG6RGpwDwVRCU33qB.name: Kyle Mathews
7qAJu2nRIRGiG6RGpwDwVRCU33qB.description: A little bit about the blazing fast React.js static site generator and why it's awesomesauce!

ATtdZaI973iLRPWVLljB5yMx27oe.title: If You Learned FRP, You'd Never Have To Use Redux Again
ATtdZaI973iLRPWVLljB5yMx27oe.name: Hannah Howard
ATtdZaI973iLRPWVLljB5yMx27oe.description:
At Carbon Five, we think reactive programming is a great way to build frontend GUI applications. We use ReactiveX, which has amazingly robust libraries across a variety of languages. We've found the concepts translate well across of a variety of client projects, platforms, and frameworks, so much so that it's almost our de facto standard way to build frontends.

We also work on React projects that use Redux. Often the Redux code becomes a pain point that slows down the rest of the project. We've begun exploring using ReactiveX's javascript library, RxJS, as an alternative to Redux, and we'd like to share what we've learned.

This talk will provide:

1. A general introduction to functional reactive programming.
2. An introduction to ReactiveX libraries
3. A broad comparison between ReactiveX and Redux

mMliZk22YgmwxWRhwhZHITTR8TdG.title: Serverless and React (it's just sleight of hand)
mMliZk22YgmwxWRhwhZHITTR8TdG.name: Marina Miranovich
mMliZk22YgmwxWRhwhZHITTR8TdG.description:
A few months ago I built a small web page, that supposed to be integrated into the existing mobile app within a webview. Even though that was only one page, it was a checkout page, so there were a lot of things going on there: a lot of API calls to verify the data, need to decrypt the params that were passed there, additionally would need to encrypt the response as well. 
First thought was - to build an server app that would return simple HTML/CSS and may have some vanila JS. But that looks too much for hosting one page, and I was really worry about scaling of it, we expected a huge peaks of load. And the final decision was to have AWS lambda render a page for us. 
So the talk would be about SSR of React app in cloud functions (particularly aws lambda).

X9hSvHw8J00H1WQcJL2qZ4EJzbqU.title: Save Money and Time with CI/CD
X9hSvHw8J00H1WQcJL2qZ4EJzbqU.name: Jeff Wainwright
X9hSvHw8J00H1WQcJL2qZ4EJzbqU.description: Discussing how Dollar Shave Club employs a CI/CD pipeline for their front end to improve velocity while saving money and engineering time.

ocEBKD2KwpNlySgj06WateqpMgd9.title: The Algorithms of CSS
ocEBKD2KwpNlySgj06WateqpMgd9.name: Lara Schenck
ocEBKD2KwpNlySgj06WateqpMgd9.description: “CSS isn’t a ‘real’ programming language,” we are often reminded — we don’t ‘program’ in CSS, we describe presentation. Algorithms and CSS, then, don’t exactly go hand-in-hand…or do they? Could CSS be a programming language?

R4RuBMa8JukaJXkCCv56Hg8QgB99.title: ML on the CL
R4RuBMa8JukaJXkCCv56Hg8QgB99.name: Kylie Stewart
R4RuBMa8JukaJXkCCv56Hg8QgB99.description: Machine learning is everywhere, but how easy is it to get started? Could your small project benefit from some simple ML? In this talk, we will cover the very basics of artificial intelligence, as well as learn a Python-free approach to big data, basic algorithms, and how easy all of this is to implement in your average shopping cart with a single Node.js file.

cT2FpLsTsv3bgSrlxmTyHptruTSd.title: Vector Money: Can we fix the root of most evil with JavaScript?
cT2FpLsTsv3bgSrlxmTyHptruTSd.name: Dave Taylor
cT2FpLsTsv3bgSrlxmTyHptruTSd.description: What if the value of every good or service was formally recognized as a million-element heterogeneous vector instead of a single scalar ironically dubbed the “price?”  In this blue sky talk, I propose a way to leverage augmented reality, machine learning, computer vision, and MMO game design to deliver a wholesale replacement for our current system of commerce.

P61t0X6kqMcWoQP5BrKKiUgK8kAB.title: Next-Generation Frontend Testing with Cypress.io
P61t0X6kqMcWoQP5BrKKiUgK8kAB.name: Amir Rustamzadeh
P61t0X6kqMcWoQP5BrKKiUgK8kAB.description: In this talk you'll learn how to write flake-free and deterministic end-to-end and unit tests that run in a real browser with Cypress.io, a testing tool for the modern web.

VJ1qqJGD6olkGU1dAW3dVYgBYrRu.title: JavaScript: It's a feature, not a bug
VJ1qqJGD6olkGU1dAW3dVYgBYrRu.name: Michael Anthony
VJ1qqJGD6olkGU1dAW3dVYgBYrRu.description: I'd like to talk about JavaScripts large role in our studio's production process and how it's flexibility allows us to define our own rigidity. I'll also go into how we use C++, Swift, Java/Kotlin to extend JavaScripts abilities.

VZGEGeMac0vsPnajUD7RobqLYV0e.title: A day in the life of a Node.js Core Contributor
VZGEGeMac0vsPnajUD7RobqLYV0e.name: James M Snell
VZGEGeMac0vsPnajUD7RobqLYV0e.description: A Day in the life of a Node.js core contributor. This talk will candidly pull back the curtain on how things work within the Node.js core project, including how we get things done, how decisions are made, and insights into how to get involved.

gPi9oCGc5XHuHxFY4km2Ki1pQc79.title: Create Electronic Dance Music with JavaScript!
gPi9oCGc5XHuHxFY4km2Ki1pQc79.name: Walmik Deshpande
gPi9oCGc5XHuHxFY4km2Ki1pQc79.description: When you go to a party, what is the most common thing about the music? It's repetitive! As engineers, what comes to mind when we see something repeating again and again? Automate the damn thing! \m/ Using simple String and Array functions we'll put together a miniature electronic dance track with the host of options available today right in the browser with the Web Audio API as well as on the terminal with Node.js! All you need is a little bit of JavaScript and a little bit of interest in music :)

WmIq6QiadkaemwpYHwcBdI6S4LmZ.title: The Outsourcing Rollercoaster
WmIq6QiadkaemwpYHwcBdI6S4LmZ.name: Alli McKee
WmIq6QiadkaemwpYHwcBdI6S4LmZ.description: I'd love to talk about what it's like to build an early stage product with an outsourced team, both the pros and cons. First with a team in China, then in the Ukraine with a CTO here, then solely with a team in the Ukraine + NYC. Learnings that can be applied to teams big and small, especially in the early stages of a product.

0ne2pe81EWkn4N6BEEEiFuvd1Kl0.title: LoopBack at Wordnik
0ne2pe81EWkn4N6BEEEiFuvd1Kl0.name: Erin McKean
0ne2pe81EWkn4N6BEEEiFuvd1Kl0.description:
In this talk you'll learn:

how to connect LoopBack to your datasource
how to create a model
how to add a custom method
... and more!

QyfRnazTTarToyyyvThfBHbkxyql.title: Render All Over the Damn Place with React Native
QyfRnazTTarToyyyvThfBHbkxyql.name: Greg Westneat
QyfRnazTTarToyyyvThfBHbkxyql.description:
This talk is about the concept of "cross-platform rendering," where one set of view-layer primitives can be used as abstractions to render across different platforms' view-APIs. 
"Web? iOS & Android? TV!? All with one 'effin set of templates?" Youbetcha. 
This talk will focus on how React Native is used for cross-platform development, and cover some of the prominent technologies and challenges involved in making "Universal" React Native apps for web and mobile.

ECOLwuuGJWevLnXtoY1KhZZZbME1.title: Serverless Microservices with AWS Lambda and API Gateway
ECOLwuuGJWevLnXtoY1KhZZZbME1.name: Alex Tamoykin
ECOLwuuGJWevLnXtoY1KhZZZbME1.description:
This talk is about serverless microservices with AWS Lambda and API Gateway. 
We'll talk about pros and cons of using serverless as well as microservices, and I'll demonstrate how to set it up with AWS Lambda and API Gateway.

FtswKzHP0CQlUau1O2OVoppfj1k4.title: Ethics huh!? What is it good for?
FtswKzHP0CQlUau1O2OVoppfj1k4.name: Ryan Bogle
FtswKzHP0CQlUau1O2OVoppfj1k4.description: An everyday ethical approach to software engineering

01Po92a9fIrpNBwEGyzvhXqZ0eHQ.title: Monkey Patching CSRF Away
01Po92a9fIrpNBwEGyzvhXqZ0eHQ.name: Joe Rozner
01Po92a9fIrpNBwEGyzvhXqZ0eHQ.description: Despite solutions in many modern frameworks Cross Site Request Forgery (CSRF) still remains an elusive problem for web application security. While we have good and proven solutions it's not uncommon to still see these vulnerabilities in modern and legacy applications in use today. Typically this is due to the solutions not being utilized by the engineers, the application's framework not having support, or the engineers subverting the functionality to work around issues in the application. We'll take a deep dive into just how CSRF works followed by why the vulnerability class exists, and finally end demonstrating a solution that can be injected into any JavaScript frontend application to add support to existing applications.

6sa2sgF0jtvUuVw4Wk6lVYqG7EPA.title: Becoming a programmer without a degree or a bootcamp
6sa2sgF0jtvUuVw4Wk6lVYqG7EPA.name: Ben Junya
6sa2sgF0jtvUuVw4Wk6lVYqG7EPA.description: I'd like to talk about my non-traditional way of getting into the field of programming and software engineering.

XnXPUvNFHRKBDtBp1f4Vfe7fUCGK.name: James M Snell
XnXPUvNFHRKBDtBp1f4Vfe7fUCGK.description: Showing off some of the fun stuff you can do with HTTP/2! Talk about some best practices and a bit about what may be coming down the road...

0S0DO9BMsOMpkjXQw6AfETUTUqM2.description: Discussing how Dollar Shave Club employs a CI/CD pipeline for their front end to improve velocity while saving money and engineering time.

0lnaJtcpRdPzMThBVcyzgeNOfv93.name: Max Harris
0lnaJtcpRdPzMThBVcyzgeNOfv93.title: You Might Not Need Browser Layout
0lnaJtcpRdPzMThBVcyzgeNOfv93.description: I built a library that helps you build UIs that render to pure SVG (no HTML, no CSS). It handles layout without relying on the browser's layout engine, implements its own shape picking system, events, provides a scrollable text-wrapping component, replaces the browser's input element with a new one, supports drag-and-drop, has a built-in dynamic layout editor, and is currently a React library

2BqlSBjGIZUAAbHUdgsaxNFBLGb2.title: 6 Months of PureScript in Production
2BqlSBjGIZUAAbHUdgsaxNFBLGb2.description: I work for CitizenNet / Conde Nast. About a year ago we were looking to move away from a legacy Angular application. We looked at React, Elm and Reason but ultimately decided on PureScript. I would like to talk about why we decided to go with PureScript instead of another technology, how we are approaching our migration, and how has it gone now that we have had PureScript in production for a little of 6 months.

3eE4pBC36EhOmRNWsYCaH3QdEwk1.name: Tony Germaneri
3eE4pBC36EhOmRNWsYCaH3QdEwk1.title: How I made a table with 10 million rows
3eE4pBC36EhOmRNWsYCaH3QdEwk1.description:
I had a requirement to show tens of thousands of rows of data for a client, the solution? Use immediate drawing mode canvas to create a virtual table of much data.

I'd like to talk about algorithm complexity (big O notation) issues encountered while dealing with large arrays and in general how it effects front end web performance. If there's time, we can even go over using the web component spec to create the project aka the new hotness.

5Cg41DXrH4MYDxxpj9Vz6gTpMcl1.name: Adam Smith
5Cg41DXrH4MYDxxpj9Vz6gTpMcl1.title: Get Over Yourself
5Cg41DXrH4MYDxxpj9Vz6gTpMcl1.description: A humbling look into Imposter Syndrome and realizing you’re not the only one. Getting comfortable with being uncomfortable is something we all need to get comfortable with.

7XNE9jKonGNeFvDVpzKJT3oDRM72.name: Francis Potter
7XNE9jKonGNeFvDVpzKJT3oDRM72.title: The Code to Happiness: How to Deal with Difficult Clients
7XNE9jKonGNeFvDVpzKJT3oDRM72.description:
A brief and playful presentation with practical techniques for dealing with difficult clients, managing expectations, and -- most importantly -- how to tell a client you're behind schedule so they leave the meeting feeling satisfied. 

Francis Potter has been writing code and keeping paying clients happy for over 30 years.

7jmLI9t0A1eft3YJXBV5r1ncUiC2.name: Fabien Lemaitre
7jmLI9t0A1eft3YJXBV5r1ncUiC2.title: 🎼Web Audio Visualization Applied to Speech 🗣
7jmLI9t0A1eft3YJXBV5r1ncUiC2.description: How do you leverage web technologies for visualizing speech? We'll cover a bit of the theory behind the Web Audio apis and libraries. Then we'll look at different ways we can visualize the vocal audio data. Finally, we'll explore more advanced techniques such as real time vocal analysis.

80OBMeWHH0fsmUD0i1heQZ54Adp1.name: Shawn swyx Wang
80OBMeWHH0fsmUD0i1heQZ54Adp1.title: JAM Stack: The Total Victory of JavaScript
80OBMeWHH0fsmUD0i1heQZ54Adp1.description:
A lot has happened in the five years since Val Karpov coined the MEAN stack to describe "Full Stack" Javascript stacks.
React rose to dominance, AWS Lambda started the Serverless movement, and Static Site Generators came back in a big way. 


What is driving this new stack of Javascript, APIs, and Markup? This is the story of how a JAM Stack cynic finally turned into a believer.

AyQsQugwl7PhVPc4fyoWV2tO9z03.name: Paul Frazee
AyQsQugwl7PhVPc4fyoWV2tO9z03.title: The Peer-to-peer Web
AyQsQugwl7PhVPc4fyoWV2tO9z03.description:
We love the Web because it's open, free, and highly connected. But sometimes the Web falls short: big businesses are centralizing control, data is getting tied up on servers, and users are losing their privacy.

How can we solve these problems, and decentralize the Web?

Let's take a fresh look at peer-to-peer technologies, and see just how far the Web can go with a new protocol in the browser.

BfeCqLV9gOhY8Gdmjo0pIuqNxJs2.name: Hannah Howard
BfeCqLV9gOhY8Gdmjo0pIuqNxJs2.title: If You Learned FRP, You'd Never Have To Use Redux Again

This talk will provide:

1. A general introduction to functional reactive programming.
2. An introduction to ReactiveX libraries

BjHQMncWhFaYycxE9Henmqyt4nA2.title: Punch Life
BjHQMncWhFaYycxE9Henmqyt4nA2.description: Life's not about how hard of a hit you can give... it's about how many you can take, and still keep moving forward.

H7w9yOADo4NNunzS8gRrNY0Vkc33.title: Wheels, Gears and Labyrinths
H7w9yOADo4NNunzS8gRrNY0Vkc33.description: Jim Bumgardner has been making and publishing free puzzles at Krazydad.com since 2005. The site now offers over a million puzzles, free to download and print. Jim has worked for over 30 years as a computer software developer and is also a pianist and composer.

HEvJkPw50mP7yGBjJf2fyqmWu7k1.name: Joe Vargas
HEvJkPw50mP7yGBjJf2fyqmWu7k1.title: Asking "What ifs" and APIs
HEvJkPw50mP7yGBjJf2fyqmWu7k1.description:
Admittedly, I actively avoided JavaScript for nearly a decade.
I waded through a breadth of timeless CS topics, languages of various paradigms, and cornerstone technologies instead.
Fortunately, the web's all consuming power learned me to embrace it.
That meant getting a day job writing, maintaining, and integrating APIs.
Still being new to webdev, the whole API process felt awfully tedious.

With group discussion at the workplace, we endlessly debated standardizing to Thrift, Avro, Protobuf, or GraphQL among many others.
Before I realized how fractured the Thrift community was, I fixed the Apache* Thrift compiler to produce the minimally compilable Haskell code.
The work group debate was still going nowhere. Thrift was off the table again. From spite I asked myself, "Why not write another IDL?"

Over the months, I iterated between imaginary specs and prototype code. I developed a general direction for where this fetal IDL will go.
 
I quit my job. Unrelated. The opportunity now shown itself to go head first into the IDL. Another project would serve as a driving force for design.

Jumping back and forth between the projects formed a symbotic relationship between them.
Having a practical project, the IDL's "killer app", exposed many devilish details with the IDL. The countless tweaks left it with a more practical flavor.
Of course, having a project actually use the IDL is motivating in itself. I have a glimpse into the flexibility and ease for next-gen APIs. Well, at least for my APIs.

I want to share more than some unique technical aspects of the IDL but also the process and consequential advantages of developing projects symbotically.

IDL: https://www.colorless-idl.org
Other Project: https://www.camp47.com

HabvGsfwLsP7r4b3RssN6cx68Qx1.name: James M Snell
HabvGsfwLsP7r4b3RssN6cx68Qx1.title: A day in the life of a Node.js Core Contributor
HabvGsfwLsP7r4b3RssN6cx68Qx1.description: A Day in the life of a Node.js core contributor. This talk will candidly pull back the curtain on how things work within the Node.js core project, including how we get things done, how decisions are made, and insights into how to get involved.

HjdCcUCvyVdVv3A7dtqhuMFF1522.name: Loren Stewart
HjdCcUCvyVdVv3A7dtqhuMFF1522.title: Query the shit out of Facebook's Graph API (I can change the title...)
HjdCcUCvyVdVv3A7dtqhuMFF1522.description:
How to interact with Facebook's Graph API (searching, posting, etc.) from Node using just regular http requests (I'll use request-promise).  

All the npm packages for making this task easier are VERY out of date (3+ years), so this is a roll-your-own solution that'll last as long as this version of FB's api.

IDtDQpL23NNIX7LBMmnvkVopSa23.title: TBD

Something awesome, I just haven't decided yet...

You'll be the first to know!

J4WBrltOvjaliVEoi0JZ2RdX39w1.name: Jeffrey Hoffer
J4WBrltOvjaliVEoi0JZ2RdX39w1.title: tao.js - a new way of building applications
J4WBrltOvjaliVEoi0JZ2RdX39w1.description:
This all started 9 years ago when I thought about building a portal with admin and reporting that could easily evolve over time and provide a framework for others to add functionality.

I've been obsessed with the idea ever since with many notebook scribblings to design it, a few starts and stops on implementations, along with some theory.

In the end is a system with a meta language used to describe application states so that requirements definition between Product Managers and Engineers is clear and this same meta language translates directly to written code and testable.

Public Github and Gitbook documentation site coming soon.

Jp26xdnIAgSl8Rbw0LF3lofr0sV2.name: Forrest Akin
Jp26xdnIAgSl8Rbw0LF3lofr0sV2.title: BYOQB (Build Your Own Query Builder)
Jp26xdnIAgSl8Rbw0LF3lofr0sV2.description: Awhile back when I was a solo dev, I stumbled upon some helpful functional patterns using knex to query relational data. I've never been a huge fan of ORMs because I prefer a lean package and efficient SQL. Knex was perfect for me because it gave me just the right pieces to build a query building pipeline from small composed functions, which made my service extremely easy to reason about and modify.

KCqywYCH6dMftekREnx13A9Qinh2.name: Greg Westneat
KCqywYCH6dMftekREnx13A9Qinh2.notes:
Original Submission- 
Hey!

I'd like to talk about React Native and "universal components" by which I mean the method of writing views in RN and having them render in iOS/Android/Web/etc.

It all started when I was tasked with making a single sign on app for my company (sweetgreen) with support for web and mobile...

Since it was an internal tool, I was able to use the emergent "universal component" approach, specifically using react-native-web to compile whitelisted RN primitives to HTML/CSS.

The process has (and continues to be) somewhat uncharted and I thought that experience would be interesting to others. 

Abridged list of topics:
-responsive styling ala rem/csslocks
-automating integration testing
-CI pipeline and Code Push
-Routing/Navigation and App Linking
-much more!


Plenty enough material on the process itself to fill 30 min, but I thought I would also quickly tie together the experience writing an app in newish tech, into a commentary on how react is not the "end of history" in terms of app tech, and humble advice on contending with such a transient professional landscape.
KCqywYCH6dMftekREnx13A9Qinh2.title: Render All Over the Damn Place with React Native
