"Web? iOS & Android? TV!? All with one 'effin set of templates?" Youbetcha. 
This talk will focus on how React Native is used for cross-platform development, and cover some of the prominent technologies and challenges involved in making "Universal" React Native apps for web and mobile.

LSVSV6WFwdNfnZCLyfhZXpP2kJH2.name: Zach Holman
LSVSV6WFwdNfnZCLyfhZXpP2kJH2.title: UTC is Enough for Everybody, Right?
LSVSV6WFwdNfnZCLyfhZXpP2kJH2.description: Possibly a talk about date/time programming, but also kind of TBD.

La8pgX3msWZBBKDjse1E2nc2C2A3.name: Aaron Craig
La8pgX3msWZBBKDjse1E2nc2C2A3.title: Why you should (almost) always use stateful components in React
La8pgX3msWZBBKDjse1E2nc2C2A3.description:
In my work heading up the front end effort for a startup (still in stealth), we've adopted React / React Native / React Native Web for our client facing apps.

As a hiring manager discussing component architecture with candidates, and in general reading in blogs, etc, I notice that there is still a prevalent use of the data down / actions up pattern popularized by EmberJS and other like frameworks.

With Redux, a new paradigm is available, that allows smart, stateful components to be composed together, where each component is master of it's own domain, and very little data is shared between them through properties.

This architecture has worked very well for us so far, though it does have it's own set of complications to deal with.

I'd love to share my story of how we came to really push hard into the world of almost completely stateful components, each plugged into Redux state, and what that's meant for us in terms of code maintainability, a clean and composition based architecture, easier debugging and more!

MKGYkUwvkvUfYTbdqSm272CJkXR2.name: Nader Dabit
MKGYkUwvkvUfYTbdqSm272CJkXR2.title: Full Stack Development in the Era of Serverless Computing
MKGYkUwvkvUfYTbdqSm272CJkXR2.description:
When people think about cloud computing, they typically think about servers & back end development. This is starting to change.

With the emergence of more & more powerful & sophisticated managed services like AWS AppSync, Cloudinary, Algolia, Auth0 & Firebase, it's completely possible for front-end engineers to build full-stack web & mobile applications with almost no back-end code, relying on these services to do the heavy lifting for features like data layers, search, authentication, authorization, & more.

In this talk, I'll talk about this philosophy in depth, discuss the options available from different service providers, & then show how (live-code) to build a full-stack web application in just a few minutes by using React & AWS Amplify to quickly build a real-world application complete with a GraphQL API, authentication & authorization, & hosting.

Mz9M4ssRQ0Z70YC7lw1o5StuRSX2.name: Phillip Michael Troutman
Mz9M4ssRQ0Z70YC7lw1o5StuRSX2.title: Wait! You might not need Redux after all.
Mz9M4ssRQ0Z70YC7lw1o5StuRSX2.description:
I needed to develop a  fast React application utilizing a centralized store, but didn't have the time or patience to set up all of the Redux boiler plate. 

Luckily I was able to get creative with the the React 16.3 Context API to accomplish all the same things Redux does but in a fraction of the setup time. Also, I was able to learn a great deal about the API itself and just how flexible it can be.

NCmZKGPOOfR3o2xxdl38wqaMdm63.name: Kyle Mathews
NCmZKGPOOfR3o2xxdl38wqaMdm63.title: Building Beautiful Websites with Gatsby
NCmZKGPOOfR3o2xxdl38wqaMdm63.description: A little bit about the blazing fast React.js static site generator and why it's awesomesauce!

PtakuKqNxMQVHk3U1xwooKEtVcj2.name: Ryan Bogle
PtakuKqNxMQVHk3U1xwooKEtVcj2.title: Ethics huh!? What is it good for?
PtakuKqNxMQVHk3U1xwooKEtVcj2.description: An everyday ethical approach to software engineering

QTljOJJEA9Sckg8lqSVdbw6cTpf1.name: Kenneth Wheeler
QTljOJJEA9Sckg8lqSVdbw6cTpf1.description:
I could talk about a couple things:

WebGL in react native.
React Native Games
My new graphql library Urql
Advanced React Patterns
ReasonML

Rza1kcGeNZdcItWV7lZblWrqwaH2.name: Lara Schenck
Rza1kcGeNZdcItWV7lZblWrqwaH2.title: The Algorithms of CSS
Rza1kcGeNZdcItWV7lZblWrqwaH2.description: “CSS isn’t a ‘real’ programming language,” we are often reminded — we don’t ‘program’ in CSS, we describe presentation. Algorithms and CSS, then, don’t exactly go hand-in-hand…or do they? Could CSS be a programming language?

S6GhlGQwTXSH2VRanNmzYZaDmGX2.name: Esther Nam
S6GhlGQwTXSH2VRanNmzYZaDmGX2.title: Become a better developer with one weird trick!
S6GhlGQwTXSH2VRanNmzYZaDmGX2.description:
This is a somewhat non-technical talk -- I gave it at PyCon 2018, and can modify the code examples to Javascript.  I totally understand if it's not a good fit for js.la, though!

Description: 
Those of us who have worked in software development for longer than a few years probably feel we have an intuitive sense of what a great developer is. Some traits come more easily to mind than others when it comes to identifying a great developer. In this talk we will take a slightly different approach to evaluating software development best practices, and identify one underrated skill common to great software developers: empathy. I hope to demonstrate that cognitive and emotional empathy skills are critical to good software development. We will explore ways to cultivate this trait in order to become better developers, both for our own sakes and for the sake of the teams in which we work.

The slide deck I used at PyCon:  
http://bit.ly/pycon-empathy-talk

Video from PyCon 2018:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=IYWlfVqBQLc

Sn4Q0MCLy6UYhmyeoPyf0OadWN93.name: Evelyn Masso
Sn4Q0MCLy6UYhmyeoPyf0OadWN93.title: CoffeeScript: Good or Great?
Sn4Q0MCLy6UYhmyeoPyf0OadWN93.description: CoffeeScript is a fun, powerful tool for your next Javascript project, even if its not as popular as it used to be. I’ll dive into CoffeeScript’s latest features (and some of its best older ones), and discuss which types of projects it is best suited for.  We’ll also talk how it compares to other transpiles-to-javascript languages and some best practices for integrating it into new or existing codebases.

ULgxPL39B8SpwVFWptDCyp3czWi2.name: David Guttman
ULgxPL39B8SpwVFWptDCyp3czWi2.title: How to Outsource Your Job
ULgxPL39B8SpwVFWptDCyp3czWi2.description:
Step 1: how to work from home / remote
Step 2: how to hire your replacement on upwork
Step 3: how to manage your upworker
Step 4: how to keep yourself occupied when you have no work to do

USp8NH5it1eFoJ0Q2DHWkMQV1bB2.intro: Jasmine is an New York City based developer and Cloud Advocate at Microsoft. She uses Azure to illustrate the awesome things developers can do in the cloud. Her development experience has led her to different development environments, including her most recent engineering role at GitHub. She also teaches beginning web development at a small college and volunteers as a co-organizer of BrooklynJS, a monthly meetup held in NYC.
USp8NH5it1eFoJ0Q2DHWkMQV1bB2.name: Jasmine Greenaway
USp8NH5it1eFoJ0Q2DHWkMQV1bB2.title: The making of "Who is HorseJS?"
USp8NH5it1eFoJ0Q2DHWkMQV1bB2.description: On August 2018 two meddling and curious colleagues were booed as they walked off stage and out of the back of the presentation venue of JSConf US. Why? Because of HorseJS. This is a story about why and how they decided to take on the task of finding out who HorseJS is.

UXaa49EFmqWsjMsvDXFJblEipeZ2.name: Dave Taylor
UXaa49EFmqWsjMsvDXFJblEipeZ2.title: Vector Money: Can we fix the root of most evil with JavaScript?
UXaa49EFmqWsjMsvDXFJblEipeZ2.description: What if the value of every good or service was formally recognized as a million-element heterogeneous vector instead of a single scalar ironically dubbed the “price?”  In this blue sky talk, I propose a way to leverage augmented reality, machine learning, computer vision, and MMO game design to deliver a wholesale replacement for our current system of commerce.

UaZejwJ1EIeZlpLcXOy3nlPwv8s1.name: Aliaksandr Yankouski
UaZejwJ1EIeZlpLcXOy3nlPwv8s1.title: Software Engineer
UaZejwJ1EIeZlpLcXOy3nlPwv8s1.description: I would like to share my experience about creating first game in JavaScript and ways of dealing with graphics in browsers in a nutshell. And just how I was playing with WebGL and what I finally got.

VHMJs41EwsZ9OWxFR3lM3sFqmAJ2.name: David Guttman
VHMJs41EwsZ9OWxFR3lM3sFqmAJ2.title: The Rise of the Sound-Reactive, Beat-Detecting, Robotic Browser VJ

Vcx9dvGjFRQdjVpeR3mEA8pesCm1.name: Andrew Henderson
Vcx9dvGjFRQdjVpeR3mEA8pesCm1.title: Getting to App Store: React Native & Firebase
Vcx9dvGjFRQdjVpeR3mEA8pesCm1.description:
My experience building my first iOS app, Swizzle, using React Native and getting it in the App Store:
https://appsto.re/us/oRPNhb.i

Below is the title and description I drafted:

---

Getting to App Store: React Native & Firebase

As a JavaScript engineer with over 10 years of professional Web development experience, Andrew Henderson single-handedly built his first native iOS app using React Native and Firebase.

In this talk, he will cover the tools he chose, the pain points he experienced, and the most important lessons he learned when crossing over from Web to native iOS.

---

I reached out to both both you and React Native LA at the same time. They got back to me immediately because they had a spot open up at next week's meetup, so I'm scheduled to give a presentation on Thursday. Hopefully, you don't mind me speaking there as well.

Looking forward to your reply.

VgKBIfegO4Nd3ePf2tWBMvkQrO32.name: Abhi Aiyer
VgKBIfegO4Nd3ePf2tWBMvkQrO32.title: Web Performance with Webpack
VgKBIfegO4Nd3ePf2tWBMvkQrO32.description: Introduction to Webpack and its benefits.

X0vUDHfWkNURqApu9ZCEICVRDbG2.name: Maxim Salnikov
X0vUDHfWkNURqApu9ZCEICVRDbG2.title: Service Worker: taking the best from the past experience for the bright future of PWAs
X0vUDHfWkNURqApu9ZCEICVRDbG2.description:
I have a variety of sessions about PWA, Service Workers, Angular, Workbox, Modern web. Check all the info here: https://sessionize.com/maxim-salnikov/

I supported SoCal Code Camp in LA by my sessions two times, I'm a big fan of your city :)

X5IMvekuxacgAtSxY6SR4aSF4463.name: Jarrett Harris
X5IMvekuxacgAtSxY6SR4aSF4463.title: NodeSchool: When I Met You, I Was But the Learner, Now I am the Master
X5IMvekuxacgAtSxY6SR4aSF4463.description: Talk about my experience running and mentoring at NodeSchool

XaQxI2zqjHdM8dPSlNFQ4DtbFr62.name: Kristian Freeman
XaQxI2zqjHdM8dPSlNFQ4DtbFr62.title: Happy coding with TypeScript
XaQxI2zqjHdM8dPSlNFQ4DtbFr62.description:
We build cool stuff with JavaScript, but the act of writing JavaScript itself can be a nightmare. TypeScript is the best of both worlds: a typed language that compiles down to plain JavaScript.

In this talk, we'll cover the basics of TypeScript and why would a team writing JavaScript might consider using it. We'll wrap by porting a brief snippet of JavaScript code into TypeScript, to see it in action. 

* TypeScript at a high-level
* Why TypeScript?
* Features and syntax
* Rewriting JS code into TypeScript

XqTkLFbFtUdtOu5DumHm6hVbh6g1.name: Feross Aboukhadijeh
XqTkLFbFtUdtOu5DumHm6hVbh6g1.title: The Lost Art of MIDI – Bringing < bgsound > Back to the Web
XqTkLFbFtUdtOu5DumHm6hVbh6g1.description: In the days of Geocities and Angelfire, a quirky HTML tag called < bgsound > enabled sound files to play in the background of webpages. Usually, these files were in the MIDI format. What a glorious era that was! Sadly, < bgsound > has been removed from browsers and MIDI is obscure and hard to play back. In this talk, we'll bring MIDI and < bgsound > back from the dead using WebAssembly, Emscripten, Web Audio, and Web Components. When we're finished, you'll be able to give your webpages the 90's treatment in a modern, standards-compliant way!

ccL5AZqJPHQPahpcwjWnfaFmG6X2.name: Joe Rozner
ccL5AZqJPHQPahpcwjWnfaFmG6X2.title: Monkey Patching CSRF Away
ccL5AZqJPHQPahpcwjWnfaFmG6X2.description: Despite solutions in many modern frameworks Cross Site Request Forgery (CSRF) still remains an elusive problem for web application security. While we have good and proven solutions it's not uncommon to still see these vulnerabilities in modern and legacy applications in use today. Typically this is due to the solutions not being utilized by the engineers, the application's framework not having support, or the engineers subverting the functionality to work around issues in the application. We'll take a deep dive into just how CSRF works followed by why the vulnerability class exists, and finally end demonstrating a solution that can be injected into any JavaScript frontend application to add support to existing applications.

ceFKl1XqSpVdeO5e41mJEK5An5A2.name: Bex Warner
ceFKl1XqSpVdeO5e41mJEK5An5A2.title: Automating software Development with Probot
ceFKl1XqSpVdeO5e41mJEK5An5A2.description: Probot: a platform for building GitHub Apps.

cglHFfu16FUXcKjO4dnxoTSJ1K83.name: Gerard O'Neill
cglHFfu16FUXcKjO4dnxoTSJ1K83.title: Put Some Respek on My Name
cglHFfu16FUXcKjO4dnxoTSJ1K83.description:
This is a talk about all the problems that occur when programmers try to validate and sanitize names. My last name has an apostrophe, and it's a horrible experience. I know someone whose first name is one letter. I have friends with accented characters in their names.

Programmers do a horrible job of respecting people's monikers, so I am on a mission to make people understand the flaws in their ways.

I recently gave a shorter version of this talk: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YFEO0qKYaiU

e5UynVQpjebnFx1bnZ3ujKfK0z73.name: James Hush
e5UynVQpjebnFx1bnZ3ujKfK0z73.title: React and Flow in a Large Codebase
e5UynVQpjebnFx1bnZ3ujKfK0z73.description:
I'm putting together a talk about using Flow with React based on our experience migrating thousands of lines of code at the NFL.

Specifically it'll be about some of tooling we've used that aren't mentioned that often in other places (flow-runtime, eslint-plugin-flowtype, text editor plugins) and React specific Flow tricks that aren't mentioned too often (adding flow types to PropTypes, state, react refs, lifecycle methods, etc).

eKOf83YYkVNnoDaAcOayujcSrht1.name: James M Snell
eKOf83YYkVNnoDaAcOayujcSrht1.title: Having fun with HTTP/2 in Node.js
eKOf83YYkVNnoDaAcOayujcSrht1.description: Fun stuff you can do with HTTP/2! Including some best practices and future plans of HTTP2 in Node.

fJujh1F2HmQxza8kUiMoXbtbjbj1.name: Brian Mau
fJujh1F2HmQxza8kUiMoXbtbjbj1.title: Peer to Peer Video Streaming with WebRTC
fJujh1F2HmQxza8kUiMoXbtbjbj1.description: WebRTC is a technology that is rapidly stabilizing, and it belongs in your tool-belt. Lets demystify it by building a peer to peer video streaming app.

fNSYFvrXEDWFzHuemWuMPjzXo8p1.name: Keith Moore
fNSYFvrXEDWFzHuemWuMPjzXo8p1.title: bomBora -  How to hold down your Vegemite In a NonStop Sea of Waves
fNSYFvrXEDWFzHuemWuMPjzXo8p1.description:
Subtitle:
Porting and maintaining a native V8 engine in a car that never stops.
 
This talk will be a brief discussion about the continuing value, saga, and successes associated with a very special enterprise build of node.js for the HPE NonStop Server class of systems. This talk will give behind-the-scenes talk of low-level and odd design features and constraints of putting open (and semi-open) virtual machines onto a specialized operating system.

ijPbnizh8iO0J5hrstqHFh2m64F3.name: Marina Miranovich
ijPbnizh8iO0J5hrstqHFh2m64F3.title: Serverless and React (it's just sleight of hand)
ijPbnizh8iO0J5hrstqHFh2m64F3.description:
A few months ago I built a small web page, that supposed to be integrated into the existing mobile app within a webview. Even though that was only one page, it was a checkout page, so there were a lot of things going on there: a lot of API calls to verify the data, need to decrypt the params that were passed there, additionally would need to encrypt the response as well. 
First thought was - to build an server app that would return simple HTML/CSS and may have some vanila JS. But that looks too much for hosting one page, and I was really worry about scaling of it, we expected a huge peaks of load. And the final decision was to have AWS lambda render a page for us. 
So the talk would be about SSR of React app in cloud functions (particularly aws lambda).

k2uTdw4OeTOjEgYofxR3x7es4z03.name: Kurtis Rainbolt-Greene
k2uTdw4OeTOjEgYofxR3x7es4z03.title: Using Babel in a Futuristic Working Environment
k2uTdw4OeTOjEgYofxR3x7es4z03.description: I'll be talking about Babel, how it's progressed, the future of web development, and what it solves today.

mde4qrVKP5gkTxjXpHGQqGPRPm63.name: Emma Cunningham
mde4qrVKP5gkTxjXpHGQqGPRPm63.title: Goodbye, runtime errors: or, how I learned to love type safety in a functional language like Elm
mde4qrVKP5gkTxjXpHGQqGPRPm63.description: Elm and functional programming, in the context of building dynamic data-visualizations

nauMZWddLxZjnCOorHFAsQlXH7v1.name: Alex Tamoykin
nauMZWddLxZjnCOorHFAsQlXH7v1.title: Serverless Microservices with AWS Lambda and API Gateway
nauMZWddLxZjnCOorHFAsQlXH7v1.description:
This talk is about serverless microservices with AWS Lambda and API Gateway. 
We'll talk about pros and cons of using serverless as well as microservices, and I'll demonstrate how to set it up with AWS Lambda and API Gateway.

nj4qJAo8dwTsD6gthM7YSBzzeiN2.name: Alex Tamoykin
nj4qJAo8dwTsD6gthM7YSBzzeiN2.title: Type it up with Typescript
nj4qJAo8dwTsD6gthM7YSBzzeiN2.description: Javascript is easy to start with and it's easy to shoot yourself in a foot due to loose typing. Typescript brings in the best of both worlds. It adds types, interfaces, inheritance, and all that good stuff which makes it a safe and more efficient language to use. With growing community around it and full Javascript support out of the box, it makes Typescript a great candidate to take your Javascript codebase to the next level. After listening to this talk you'll have a good understanding of how to use Typescript for your project.

oMmBp9sQqMWHk3d2YYJHxXbHzr82.name: Zev Youra
oMmBp9sQqMWHk3d2YYJHxXbHzr82.title: Narrative Visualizations
oMmBp9sQqMWHk3d2YYJHxXbHzr82.description:
I recently left Google after ~4.5 years to work on some new projects. Since then, I've been spending most of my time working on multi-layered data visualizations, and would love to talk through the creation of a few examples. I could also discuss the workflow I've developed to present them both as interactive visualizations on the web and as pre-rendered videos for consumption on twitter, facebook, etc.

...on the other hand, I may have some new ideas by next year, so let's circle back a bit beforehand to make sure this is still the best topic.

oqFfdSawBzXYLYxCev2VcgHx9xX2.name: Walmik Deshpande
oqFfdSawBzXYLYxCev2VcgHx9xX2.notes:
i ve created a Node.js module called Scribbletune which has a very minimalistic API (only 3 methods). I'd like to showcase this module along with the options available to us today when it comes to creating music with JavaScript in the browser and Node.js right from the terminal. Using my module and regular JavaScript String and Array functions I will put together the basic structure of an Electronic Dance Music track and show how easy it is for you to start dabbling with EDM using JavaScript.

Requirements

Since this talk is primarily around dance music with JS, a good sound is required (If the venue is not too big, I can get my own sound)
I will be live coding - I will compose parts of a EDM track with JavaScript and Node.js

Past talks where I presented this topic with variations:
* JS @ PayPal
* SF Node @ GitHub HQ
* ForwardJS

If you d like to get an idea of the kind of talk it would be, you can take a look at this publicly available video of my talk at Github https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dIiwFzFvsmw

I hope you ll consider my talk worthy of your meetup. Nat Lubeck is the one who told me about this wonderful meetup when I moved to LA earlier this year. Looking forward to speaking at JS.la,

Sincerely!
oqFfdSawBzXYLYxCev2VcgHx9xX2.title: Create Electronic Dance Music with JavaScript!
oqFfdSawBzXYLYxCev2VcgHx9xX2.description: When you go to a party, what is the most common thing about the music? It's repetitive! As engineers, what comes to mind when we see something repeating again and again? Automate the damn thing! \m/ Using simple String and Array functions we'll put together a miniature electronic dance track with the host of options available today right in the browser with the Web Audio API as well as on the terminal with Node.js! All you need is a little bit of JavaScript and a little bit of interest in music :)

pjY8vnAFkdbdzFfYW2PDiXEtt9q1.name: Gregor Martynus
pjY8vnAFkdbdzFfYW2PDiXEtt9q1.title: Building Offline First apps with Hoodie
pjY8vnAFkdbdzFfYW2PDiXEtt9q1.description:
I moved to LA recently with my wife for her work. I work remotely myself as web developer. I love the Open Source community in general, and the JavaScript community in general, and have been involved in the communities we lived before in Boston, Zurich and Berlin. I would love to get more involved in LA, as we will stay for a few years at least.

My recent talks were on "Welcoming Communities" [1] at EmpireJS and Cascadia.js. I was part of the community panel at last year’s GitHub universe [2]. I talked on small modules (semantic-release & Greenkeeper) at Boston.js, and noBackend at Front-Trends [3]. I gave my first talk on Offline First at Brazil JS in 2014.

I’m one of the founding contributors to Hoodie (hood.ie) – an Open Source Backend for web applications. It stores data on the client by default and syncs whenever the connectivity allows, hence we started offlinefirst.org back in 2013. I co-organized the first "Offline Camps" [4] last year, I’ll be on a panel at SXSW and we will host a track at a conference toward the end of this year.

qqthQL4oCSOcA577Kcrcq1nUCPW2.name: Hattan Shobokshi
qqthQL4oCSOcA577Kcrcq1nUCPW2.title: Let's have a chat .. building bots in node.
qqthQL4oCSOcA577Kcrcq1nUCPW2.description:
I was recently tasked with building a bot in node that used machine learning models in the back end. While I had built some bots before, I know absolutely nothing about machine learning. 

I was able to use existing machine learning tools to build a bot that understands basic phrases and interacts with folks in a natural way. I put together a talk based on my experience learning to build conversational bots. In this presentation I'll cover best practices for building bots (such as greeting users when they join a chat) and show how easy it is to build a bot and host on Azure and Digital Ocean. 

I will use the microsoft bot framework for code samples and the demo, but this talk is focused on best practices for bots as well as easily adding machine learning and natural language processing to bots.

qt6sxFaQeHPc0sOiJ8M8S06un4O2.name: Justin Dorfman
qt6sxFaQeHPc0sOiJ8M8S06un4O2.title: Let’s talk about SRI
qt6sxFaQeHPc0sOiJ8M8S06un4O2.description: Subresource Integrity (SRI) is an up and coming web security standard from the W3C. SRI enables browsers to verify that files are delivered without unexpected manipulation. This talk will go over the history and ways to generate SRI hashes so you can start protecting your end users.

rS0muY6lU1c5sqfsNmV0J9fqUvj2.name: Michael Anthony
rS0muY6lU1c5sqfsNmV0J9fqUvj2.title: The why and how of building a browser in JavaScript
rS0muY6lU1c5sqfsNmV0J9fqUvj2.description: In my previous js.la talk I showed why JavaScript's flexibility makes it a great environment for creative work. Now I'll present the conclusion of that effort and talk about what I've learned building a browser runtime on iOS, Android, Magic Leap, and even desktop using Node.

s7eB1DNkY4bYDO9J6dv46HaDoyq1.abstract: lessons I learned about a project I was working on: batching dom operations
s7eB1DNkY4bYDO9J6dv46HaDoyq1.name: Nima
s7eB1DNkY4bYDO9J6dv46HaDoyq1.title: Lessons learned during the design of a virtual machine to batch dom operations in Gecko

tSyhodfrTEZ9wco2XnAG46JPQRS2.name: Michael Anthony
tSyhodfrTEZ9wco2XnAG46JPQRS2.title: JavaScript: It's a feature, not a bug
tSyhodfrTEZ9wco2XnAG46JPQRS2.description: I'd like to talk about JavaScripts large role in our studio's production process and how it's flexibility allows us to define our own rigidity. I'll also go into how we use C++, Swift, Java/Kotlin to extend JavaScripts abilities.

vXD7TvCyr7UdX2xARWMppFXLbNm1.name: Justin Reynard
vXD7TvCyr7UdX2xARWMppFXLbNm1.title: Cross Platform Game Development with Javascript! What!
vXD7TvCyr7UdX2xARWMppFXLbNm1.description: My new company makes an online collectible card game front to back with JS. NodeJS backend, MongoDB, ReactJS front end, Redux with component/container architecture to share code with react-native

yQrBZrdo1eMw7KCL1eDMtUmk3em2.name: Lauren Spiegel & Giorgio Regni
yQrBZrdo1eMw7KCL1eDMtUmk3em2.title: High Performance Node.js: learn how to full throttle your code

ye2NBVuJjPSo49EP0004ROtwr9y1.name: Mike Kerr
ye2NBVuJjPSo49EP0004ROtwr9y1.title: From WordPress to React while keeping everyone happy.
ye2NBVuJjPSo49EP0004ROtwr9y1.description: Getting my company, FabFitFun, off a monolithic WordPress app and on to React, a change I wanted to make in the company and yelled loud enough to get the attention and approval of everyone. Discussing what it took from gaining approval from the tech team and executive stakeholders as well as how I assembled the tool to keep both Content Editors, UX Designers and Engineers happy. This initiative led me to building a custom React CMS + WYSIWIG Editor from scratch!

6vitOjvBRKaLHoWoJ2LnfDwWDMh1.goal:
Hi, We would like to sponsor because we are always searching for strong js developers for our clients in the LA area. We also want to build brand awareness.
People Tree is a recruiting company focused on tech in LA, primarily the South Bay area.

I am scheduled to sponsor another event on the same date, but they are running into some issues. I should be able to confirm by Friday.

Thanks,
Natasha
6vitOjvBRKaLHoWoJ2LnfDwWDMh1.name: Natasha Myers

7dWlfgO8j5g1u4wcNYabSOuCtXu2.goal: We'd like the JS community to know more about the awesome work we're doing here at Dollar Shave Club and we'd like more awesome engineers to join our team.
7dWlfgO8j5g1u4wcNYabSOuCtXu2.name: Dana Fleur

8JqTgC9nlvSjY3j13HzZnv9SS4Q2.goal: We're looking to hire JS engineers and build product awareness.
8JqTgC9nlvSjY3j13HzZnv9SS4Q2.name: Jade Brown

CRpefhU1JOd2yo2OEKkbiudqDXz2.goal:
